Canwyr, (plean) i (blaenio) byrdde. A joyners plane.
Canymdaith, canlyn, cŷdgerdded. To follow or accompany.
Canymdoi, gwated, amddir ffynu. To defend, protect, or conduct.
Canys, oblegid, o herwydd. Am, for, becauſe.
Cappan côr, mâth ar gap a wiſgau'r offeiriaid. A biſhops mitre, a canonical Cap.
Capten) neu Câd-pen, pen y gâd, canwriad. A captain.
Cargychwyn, treigl ddŷn, rhodiennŷdd. A vagabond, a wanderer.
Car, cer, gar, agos, garbron. Near to, or nigh unto.
Cardawd, cerdod. An alm or charity given to the poor.
Cardottai, cardotteion, rhai yn cordotta. Beggers.
Carddagl, godre. The hem, border or fringe of a garment.
Caredd, pechod, bai. A ſin, crime, or offence.
Caregl, Phiol neu gwppan yfed. A cup or jug to drink with.
Carfan. A rail or peice of wood.
Carfan gwelu, erchwyn gwelu, pren gwelu. A bedſtead, or the ſide of a bed.
Carfan gwŷdd neu gwehŷdd. A weaver's beam.
Carl, delph, Cybŷdd. A clown, a miſer.
Carn. A balft or handle, alſo the boof of a beaſt.
Carrai, carre. A thong of leather, &c.
Carregan, carreg fechan. A little ſtone.
Carregos, cerrigos, cerrig mân. Small ſtones.
Carth, carthion. Tow, or the worſt of hemp or flax.
Carthu. To clean ſiables or cowhouſes, &c.
Cartrefu, trigo, aroſ To dwell or inhabit.
Carwnaid, naid carŵ. A ſtags leap.
Caſeg y dryghin. The corniſh choff, a joy.
Caſglu, cynnull. To collect or gather.
Caſnor, llîd. Malice, envy, an itching anger.
Caſtellu, amgylchu. To encompaſs round about.
Caſul,) math ar ddilledyn i offeiriad. A prieſts garment, a caſſeck.
Catt, briwſin, briwſionyn. A crumb or little piece.
Catgi, cî mawr, (maſtiff). A great dog or maſtiff.

Catgun. cledd, cleddyf, hefyd rhefelwr, gwr bonheddig. A
ſword, a Warriour, a Nobleman, or a Gentleman.
Catyrfa, catorfa, tyrfa o wŷr, A company of men.
Catorfod, Brwydr, Rhyfel, Ymladdfa. War, a Fight or Batle.
Cathl, cân, caniad. A Song, or Canticle.
Cathlŷdd, cantor. A Singer, a Muſician.
Cathrain, gyrrwr ychen. One that drives the oaen or plough as ſome calls it.
Cau. To ſhut up, to hedge in, to cover.
Caudod, ceudod. The paunch of the belly.
Caul, cylla. The Runnet that curdeth milk.
Cawdd, dîg, digllonrhwydd. Offence, wrath, anger
Coddi, diggio. To provoke, to anger.
Cawell Pyſgotta. A Wheel, a Bew-net for fiſhing.
Cawl, gruel neu bottes. Gruell, Pottage.
Cawſai, cardota caws. To bog cheeſe,

div.head: CE.
div.p: Ceccru, ymremmial. To ſcold or quarrel.
Ceccreth, ymryſon, ymremmial. Scolding, quarrelling, ſtrife.
Cêdd, Bûdd, mael, enill. Profit, gain, benefit.
Cêdrwydd, bonheddig, da ei Rywogaeth, hael. Genero is, bountiful, noble, gentile.
Cedr, cedrwŷdd, Coed mawr Têg yn tyfu yngwlâd Affricca. The Cedar trees.
Cefn. The back, a Butt or Ridge of ground.
Cefnogi. To grow bold, fearleſs or ſtrong.
Cefndedŷn, cyndedyn, cymdedyn. The middle of the bowels and intrails, the double skin that faſtens the back and bowels.
Cefnderwedd, cefnderoedd, cefnderydd. The firſt Cozens males.
Cegid. A kind of wild reeds or roots called hemlock.
Ceibio. To dig with a mattock.
Ceidron, cadr, cadarn, gwrymmus. Strong, ſtout, valiant.
Ceifn, câr o'r bedwerydd râdd, gorŵŷr. A Nephew's Nephew, of the fourth degree.
Ceifnaint, ceraint o'r bedwerydd râdd. Kinſmen of the fourth degree.
Ceilliau. The gods of the privies.
Ceinmŷg, ceinfŷg, ceinmŷged urddas, anrhydedd, parch. Honour, reverence, eſteem, reputation.
Ceinmygu, anrhydeddu, perchi. To honour, repute, regard or eſteem.
Ceinmŷn, ymdrechu. A quarrel, combat, duell.
Ceintach, tynnu cleddyfau, amrafaelu. To draw ſwords, to ſtrive, to contend.
Ceirs, cyrs, corſydd. Wettiſh medow grounds, Moores.
Ceiſiad, y tryſorwr penaf. Lord high Treaſurer.
Celain. The body of him that was ſlain.
Celanedd. A company of dead bodies.
Celfi. Implements or tools, alſo ware or commodities.
Celffaint, hên goed crinion. Old rotten timber or wood.
Celffeinio, gwŷwo, crîno. To wither, rott or decay.
Celi, un o henway Duw. A name of God.
Celwŷddog. Lying or given to lye.
Celli, llwyn cŷll. A grove of hazel-trees.
Celliwig, llŷs y Brenin Arthur. King Arthurs palace.
Cenn pyſgod. The ſcales of fiſh.
Cen y cerig. The moſs that groweth on ſtones.
Cen y coed. The moſs that groweth on trees.
Cenaw, cî jeuangc, neu genau llwynog neu arth. A whelp, a young cub.
Cenedlu. ynnill plant, eppilio. To beget or ingender.
Cedhedlawr, pen-cenedl. The top of a family.
Cenhedlig, or un tŷ neu genedl. Of the ſame houſe or family.
Cenfaint, mintau o fôch. A berd of ſwine.
Cengl. A girth or a girdle.
Cengliadur, clynhiadur. The blades or wheel to wind thread upon.
Cennad. An ambaſſadour, a meſſenger, alſo leave or permiſſion.
Cenniattau, rhoi cennad. To permit, give leave, or grant.
Cerdd, dôs, rhodia. Walk thou, go thou.
Cernod. A box on the ear.
Cernodio. To box about the head.
Cerrŷnt, rhedfa, ſiwrnau, A courſe, race, or journey.
Cerwŷn. A brewing tun, or tub.
Ceryddu, coſpi. To chaſtiſe or correct.
Ceſtog, un a bol mawr. Having a great paunch or belly.
Cethr, Cethren, hoel, (pin), llŷw llong, llywoi draeth, corn ar fŷs. A nail, a pin. a ſtern of a ſhip: alſo government, a corn on the finger or toe.
Cethrawl, neu cythrawl, y peth a bigo fal (pin.) That which pricks like a pin.
Ceubal, cafn, cŵch, (hôt), carchar caeth. A boat, a cloſe priſon.
Ceulo. To congeal or wax thick.
Ceugant, ſiccr, diogel. Sure, certain, firm.

div.head: CI.
div.p: Ci coeg, cî 'r mor, mâth ar byſgodyn. A ſea-dog.
Cibin, cibau, peiſwyn ŷd. The husks of corn or flax, &c.
Cidŷll, cidŷll côch, mith ar walch, ceinllyf goch. A kind of hawk called a Keſtrel or Kaſtrel.
Cidwm, blaidd, (Rôg) A wolf. alſo a rogue.
Cidymmes, blaiddes, puttain. A ſhe-wolf, alſo a harlot.
Cigcai, cardotta cîg. To beg fleſh.
Cigyddio. To butcher, to tear or mangle.
Cigle, ciglef, clywed, neu fe a glybu. To hear, or rather be heard.
Cîl. Out of the way, cut of ſight.
Ciliad, cilŷdd, un ar ffo, neu'r hwn a'i gyrro. He that puts to flight, alſo he that flies.
Cilcwth, gwthiad yn ôl. A joſle, alſo repulſe.
Cilcwthio, gwthio 'n ôl. To drive back or joſle.
Cilchwŷrn, cilchwerrŷn, chwarennau. Wens or bulks in the ſkin.

Cildant, cildannau, y tannau
mân yn y delyn. The ſmaller ſtrings of the harp.
Cildyn, cyndyn, tauog. Obſtinate, dogged, churliſh.
Cilddant. One of the grinders or cheek-teeth.
Cilddor, drŵs neu lidiart fechan. A poſtern.
Cimmwch, môrgrangc. A lobſter, a crab-fiſh.
Ciniach, lliein-rhŵd, goreth. lint, a tent for a wound.
Cinynio, darnio, rhwygo. To tear, cut or rend.
Cippiad, môr-leidr. A pirate or ſea-robber.
Cippŷll, bonion coed mân. The ſtubles of ſmall wood, alſo a block.
Cîs, dyrnod. A ſtroke, ſtripe or blow.
Ciwdawd, Teyrnas, pobl. A Nation, a People.
Ciwed, tyrfa. A troop, a multitude, a rabble.

div.head: CL.
div.p: Clafdŷ, hyſpyttŷ, luſendŷ i'r cleifion. An hoſpital.
Clefyccian, bôd yn afiachus. To be ſickly.
Clafr, clefri, clefrŷd, gwahanglwyf, crâch tros yr holl gorph. The leproſie.
Clais. The print or mark of a blow.
Clais dŷdd, gwawr ddŷdd. The break of day.
Cleiſio, gwawrlo. To make black and blue ſpots in the skin with beating, alſo to break into day.
Clamp. A huge one, a great one.
Clâs, cottel mynachlog. The cloiſter of a church.
Clau vpright, ſincere, true to truſt.
Clawr, caead. A lid or cover.
Clorŷn, caead bychan, ŵy bychan. A little lid or cover, a little egg.
Clawr y ddaear, tywarchen. A clod of earth.
Cledr, cledren. The beam or rafter of a houſe, alſo a ſword amongſt the ancients.
Cledr y llaw. The palm of the hand.
Cledr y ddwyfron. The breaſt-plate, alſo the breaſt.
Cleddiwig, mur o gerrig, craig lle' coder cerig, A quarry of ſtone, a ſtone-wall.
Cleddŷf bleddŷn, cleddau biſwail, dueg. The ſpleen or milt.
Clefyccian, bôd yn afiachus. To be ſickly.
Clegŷr, cleger. To gaggle or cry like geeſe.
Cleirch, cleiriach. A decrepit old man.
Clêr y dom, y cerddorion gwaela. The viler or baſer ſort of Muſicians.
Clera, Going about with muſick playing a begging.
Clermwnt, clerwr. A muſician that begs by playing.
Cliccied. The latch of a door; alſo the jaw-bone.
Clindarddach, godeithio. Crackling as fire uſe to do.
Cloig, cloigyn, clo bychan. A little lock.
Cloccian fel ŵŷ. To cluck like a rotten egg.
Clôch neu gluch y dwr. Bubble or bubbles of water.
Clôch yr ymadrodd, gene 'r gwddw. The top of the throat.
Clochŷdd. A Clerk or Sexton, a Bell-man.
Clodfan, canmoledig. Laudable, excelling in praiſe.
Cloer. A ſpace like a little cupboard left in a wall to lay things out of band.
Clofen, cangen. A bough, a branch.
Cloffi. To grow lame, to lame.
Clogwŷn. A ſteep rock, a top hanging of one ſide.
Clol, y groenen ſy ar Aſgwrn y pen. The skin that covers the skull.
Clora, hel cnau 'r ddaiar. To gather earth-nuts.
Cloren, cynffon. The tail of any thing.
Cludair, pentwr o goed. A heap or pile of wood.
Cludeirio, pentyrru, tyrru. To pile or heap.
Clul, cnul, cnîll, caniad clŷch tros y marw. A paſſing-bell.
Clwccian fel iàr. To cluck as a ben.
Clwm, cwlm, cwlwm. A knot or tie.
Clŵŷd y ddwŷ fron. The breaſt-plate.
Clwŷden o ià. A flake of ice.
Clwŷf y Brenin, neu 'r maenwnne. The King's evil.
Y Clwŷf digwŷdd, y clwŷf tegla, y ffeintiadau. The Falling evil.
Y Clwŷf gwahanol, y clwyf mawr, edrych gwahanglŵyf.
Clyr, clyryn, mâth ar gaccwn. a kind of waſps.
Clŷw, y clywed. The hearing, hear thou.
Clywed. Heard, to hear, the hearing.
Clywittor, clywir hyn. Let it be heard.

div.head: CN.
div.p: Cnap neu hwrrwg. A bunch or lump.
Cnawdol. Carnal, lead by the fleſh.
Cnewŷll, cnywŷll, cnewyllyn, cynhwyllyn. A kernel.
Cnippws, cnoccell. A clapping or knocking.
Cnith, yſgafn deimlad. A little ſoft touch.
Cnithio, teimlo 'n yſgafn. To touch or ſmile gently.
Cnocc). A ſtroke, a ſtripe or knock.
Cnoccell. A fillip or ſlapping the fingers.
Cnofa. The griping of the guts.
Cnud, gŷrr o fleiddiaid. A flock of wolves.
Cnuwch, gwâllt y pen. The hair of the head.
Cnydio. To grow or become a crop.

div.head: CO.
div.p: Côchi. To wax red, to bluſh.
Codded, dîg, digofaint. Wrath, anger, diſpleaſure.
Coddi, digio, diglloni. To be diſpleaſ'd, to wax angry.
Coddiant, niwed, drŵg, briw. Harm, hurt, offence.
Coddŷn, canolffos heol lle rhêd y bryntni, gaudŷ. A channel, ſink or gutter: a Houſe of office, a common ſhore.
Coedwig, dryſni o goed. A wilderneſs.
Coegen. A vain ſilly or ſaucy woman.
Coegŷn. A vain fooliſh ſawcy fellow.
Coeg lwybr, ffordd anhyſpŷs. An intractable path.
Coelio. To truſt, to credit, to believe.
Coelfain, llawenydd, newydd llawen. Joy, joyful meſſage.
Coeling, nefol, yn perthyn ir nêf. Belonging to heaven.
Coeſed, bara coeſed, bara gwynn. White bread.
Coeſgoch, yderŷn or henw hwnnw. A bird called Red-ſhank.
Coethi, (puro), glanhâu. To make clean, to purifie, to hurry about.
Cofiadur, cofiawdr, yr hwn a gadwo yſgrisenadeu coffadwriaeth. A Recorder, a Rememberer.
Cofiain, galw i gôf. To call to mind.
Cofl, coflaid, neu Cowlaid. An arm-full.
Coffa, neu Coffhâu. To bring to mind.
Coffa, neu Coffadwriaeth. Memory, mention, memorial.
Cogwrn o ŷd. A ſtalk of corn.
Coliog. Full of little beards as barley-corn.
Colwyno, mudfaethu, chware 'r fudwraig. To play the midwife.
Colŷn. A ſting, alſo a hinge.
Colledu. To loſe, bring to loſs.
Colledigaeth; diniſtr, dihenŷdd. Perdition, deſtruction, execution.
Collwŷn, llwŷn o gŷll. A grove of hazle-trees.
Combr, lliain main, (Camric). Fine linen, Cambrick.
Compod, (cwmpas) y moriŵr, A mariners compaſs

Coniach, balch. Proud.
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
Conell, cynffon, colŷn. A tail, alſo a ſting▪
Conglfaen, y garreg ynghornel mur a fo yn cynnal y deilad i fynu. A corner-ſtone.
Coppa. The top of any thing.
Copprs), (Copros) i liſo. Copperas for dyers.
Corodŷn, cydymaith. A mate, or fellow-traveller.
Corbedw, corbedwŷn, bedw iſel. Low or little birth-trees.
Cordŷn) (Cortyn), tennyn, rhâff. A rope, a cord.
Cordref, pentref, trefan. A little village.
Cordderw, y derw mân iſel. The low ſhort oak-trees.
Corddyn, colyn drŵs. A hinge of a door.
Cored, deſcynfa dwr. A great down fall of water, a cataract, a port-cullis, alſo a gulf.
Corhwyad, hwyad fechan wŷllt. A real, or little wild duck.
Corlan. A ſheeps fold; a ſheeps pen.
Corniccŷll, cornchwigl, cornor y gwaenydd, cornchwiglen. A lapwing.
Cornor), (Cornol), peniaeth ar fil o wŷr. A Colonel or Commander of a thouſand ſouldiers.
Cornwŷd. Plague, peſtilence; alſo an ulcer.
Cors, tîr gwlŷbyrog. A meoriſh ground, marſhy grounds.
Corſog, yn llawn corsŷdd. mooriſh, fenny; alſo full of reeds.
Corwgl, cwrwgl, corwg, Bôt peſgotta a wnaed o groen cephŷl o amgylch cawell. A fiſher's boat made of a horſe hide and twigs:
Corwynt, gorwynt, trywynt. A whirl wind.
Corŷn. The crown of the head or hat.
Corynrwy, plêth a wiſgai hrenin ynghylch ei ben. A diadem.
Coſgordd, goſgordd, teulu, Sir. A family, houſhould, a ſhire.
Coſtog, maſtŷff. A maſtiff, a cur-dog.
Coſtrel, (pottel, fflagen) fawr. A great flagon, a jug, a bottle.
Coſtwyo, cyſtwyo. To chaſtiſe, to reprove, to puniſh.
Cott, coth, hên ŵr, yn amla am hên ddŷn cyſoethog. An old man, moſt commonly for a warm or rich man.
Cotarmur, pais yr Arwŷddfardd. A coat of arms.
Cottwm) Cotten, bumbaſt, the nap of cloth.
Cowŷll, rhôdd gŵr iw wraig cyn priodas, prîs morwyndod. A gift given by the man before marriage to his wife; alſo the reward received for one's virginity.
Cowyllŷn, màth ar wîsg mynach neu greffyddwr. A monks cowl, or ſhort mantle.
Cowŷdd, cywŷdd. A ſong, a Verſe of ſeven ſyllables.
Cowŷn, plâ, haint, Cornwyd, Plague, peſtilence, murrain.

div.head: CR.
div.p: Crâ 'r gerddi, (garlleg), y gerddi. Garden garlick.
Crafange. The claw of a bird, a crab, or any ſuch thing, a broad hand, a paw.
Crafangaid, lloned llaw, A handful, a pawful.
Crafell. A curry-comb; alſo a wooden ſlice to turn oat cakes with.
Crafell yſgwydd, palfais, Aſgwrn coel. The ſhoulder-blade.
Craflech, ygalen i hogi ellyn. A hone.
Crâff, gefel bydoli. A pair of pinchers.
Creffyn. A brace to faſten a thing with.
Craffu. edrych yn grâff. To look ſtedfaſt.
Crain, ymddaroſtwng, ſyrthio i lawr. To caſt down or proſtrate.
Crair, y pêth a deimlo un â'i law pan fo ef yn cymeryd ei lŵ. That which the ſwearer lays his hand on to take his oath.
Creirio, cymmeryd llŵ, Tyngu. To ſwear or make an oath.
Craith o gyfarch, craith weledig. A viſible ſcar.
Cramwyth, crempogen. A fritter, a pancake.
Crap, cais. A ſnatch, and endeavour.
Crâs. Dry and hard, well bak'd, alſo ſaucy.
Craſu. To wax dry and hard.
Crau nodwydd. The eye of a needle.
Crawennu. To wax hard or cruſty.
Crawnu. To corrupt, to gather to a head.
Crebach, a fo wedi crebychu, neu wŷwo. Which is ſhrunk up, or withered.
Creccian. To cacle as a hen.
Credadŷn, crededŷn, un a goelio arall yn hawdd. A credulous perſon.
Crefyddu, gwaſanaethu Duw▪ To ſerve God.
Crefftwr. A mechanick or working tradeſman.
Cregen, lleſtr pridd. An enthen veſſel.
Cregenŷdd, crochenŷdd, gwneuthurwr lleſtri priddion. A potter.
Creglais, llais crŷg. A hoarſe ſcreaming noiſe.
Crempog, crempogen. A pancake or fritter.
Cren, cut. A ſtie, pen, or coop.
Creppa, dŷn bŷr bychan. A ſhort dwarfiſh man.
Creſtennu, crêſtio. To gather ſcurff, or grow ſcurffy or ſcabby.
Crêth, achreth. Cold, ſhaking or trembling.
Creu, gwnethur pêth o ddim fel a gwnaeth duw 'r bŷd. To create.
Creadur, pôp pêth o wneuthuriad duw. A creature.
Creu, crefu. To crave or beg earneſtly.
Creuan, padell yr ymennŷdd, pilionnen yr ymennŷdd, aſgwrn pen. The brain-pan the skull.
Cri) neu weiddi. A crying out.
Crîo), To cry or bawl out.
Crîb gwlàn. A kind of large wooll-cards.
Cribell, crîb aderyn. The comb of a cock or bird.
Cribddail, trais, cam-drêch. A rape or raviſhment, an encroachment.
Cribddeilio, treiſio, camdrechu. To commit a rape, to encroach.
Cribddeiliwr, treiſiwr. A robber, an extortioner, an encroacher.
Crimmell, crimp, mîn, ochor. The edge or point of any thing.
Crimprhew, twr o iâ. A heap of ice.
Crino. To wax brittle or rotten.
Crinwas, crintach-ddŷn. A covetous ſordid man.

Crochenŷdd, crochanwr, gwneuthurŵr
lleſtri priddion. A potter.
Croeſanaeth, anllad ymadrodd. A bawdy diſcourſe.
Croeſanair, anglod heb haeddu. A wrongful defamation.
Croeſangerdd, cerdd ddiflâs aflàn, dychan. Lewd ſongs, ſcurrilous verſes, a carping ſong.
Croeſawu. To welcome, or to make welcome.
Crôg. A croſs, alſo a hanging.
Croglith, yr amſer, ag ar gyfen i 'r amſer a Croeſhoeliwyd Crîſt, dŷdd gwener y croglith. The time that Chriſt was crucified, now called Goodfriday.
Crogpren, crogwŷdd. A gallows, a gibbet.
Crogen. A ſea-ſhell, or fiſh-ſhell, the gills of fiſh.
Crombil, croppa. The crop or gorge of a bird.
Cronell neu cronnell, grawn pyſgod. The ſpawn of fiſhes, the row of fiſhes.
Cronglwŷd. The roof of a houſe.
Cronicl), hanes hên bethau, amſer-lyfr. A chronicle.
Cronni, llynnu dŵr. To damm up waters.
Croppa). The crop or gorge of a a bird.
Croppian. To creep, to go on hands and knees.
Crôth neu leſter beichogi. A womb or veſſel of conceptions.
Crôth coes. The calf of the leg.
Crothell. A ſmall fiſh called a ſprat.
Croŷw. Sweet, fresh, not ſower milk, alſo plainneſs in ſpeech.
Croŷwder. Sweetneſs without ſaltneſs, or ſowerneſs.
Crugyn, piloryn. A wheal or pimple.
Crwban, mâth ar forgrange. A ſea-crab, or lobſter.
Crwcca, cam, wedi gwyro. Bent, crocked.
Crwm, crom. A crump or hunchback'd.
Crŵth. A muſical inſtrument called a Crowd.
Crwthor, crythor. He that plays on a Crowd.
Crwybr. The dregs of any thing.
Crwydr, rhodiennŷdd, cyfeiliornŷdd. A wanderer or vagabond.
Crwydro, cifeiliorni. To err or go aſtray, to wander.
Crwydri. Poverty, want, penury, alſo covetouſneſs.
Crybwŷll, dwyn ar gôf, mynegî, sôn am. To make mention, to declare.
Crŷdr, arf amddiffyn. A weapon of defence.
Crŷdd-dŷ. The ſhoo-makers houſe or ſhop.
Cryddiaeth, cryddaniaeth, crŷddyddiaeth. The art of ſhoo-making.
Cryfhau. To ſtrengthen, to gather ſtrength.
Crymmu. To bend, to grow crooked.
Crynog, math ar (feſur). A kind of meaſure.
Crynwraidd, anfoneddigaidd, tauogaidd. Ignoble, ungentle, ruſtick.
Crŷr, cryhŷr, crehŷr, y crŷr glàs, y crŷr llwŷd, y gwddw-grŷg. A hern or crane bird.
Cryſiaw, bryſio. To baſlen or rid away.
Crŷw i ddal pyſgod. A weel to take fiſh.

div.head: CU.
div.p: Cuchiog. Of a ſowre frowning countenance.
Cudŷn. A lock of hair or wooll, &c.
Cudon, neu cuddon, yſguthan. A wood-culver, or ring-dove.
Cuddfa. A lurking place, a place to bide in.
Cuert, cwfert, caead. A lid or covering.
Cufŷdd, hŷd y braich or pynelin i flaen y canolfŷs. A cubit.
Culhâu. To wax lean or narrow.
Cunnach, (fflagen) A jack, a flagon, a bottle.
Curas, hugan ryfel, yſtyllen fargod. A coat of maile, alſo a weather-board.
Curnen, mwdwll, pinegl clochdŷ. A ſpire, a rick of corn or hay.
Curn). The corns on the toes, the horns of a beaſt.
Cût, cûd, barcud, acrwr rheibus. A kite, a greedy extortioner.

div.head: CW.
div.p: Cwbl, y cyfan. The whole, all.
Cwblhâu. To perform, to fulfil, to compleat.
Cwccwll, (hwd) neu (fantell) a wiſgo yffeiriad o'r henffŷdd. The hood of a Catholick Prieſt called a Cawl.
Cwfaint, cymmanfa o bobl grefyddol. A covent.
Cwfert, caead. A cover or lid.
Cwgn, cymmal. A joynt or knuckle.

Cygnog, cymmalog. Full of
joynts, alſo having great joynts.
Cŵl, bai, pechod. A fault, a ſin.
Cwlio), deffol y dâ oddiwrth y drŵg. To ſeparate good from bad, to pick and cull.
Cwliedig, wedi eu (Cwlio). culled or picked.
Cwlis, deſcynfa dwfr. A cataract, a gulf or great downfall of waters.
Cwlm, clwm, cwlwm. A knot or tye.
Cwll, cylla. The paunch of the belly, alſo the ſtomach.
Cwmm neu glŷn. A dale, a valley between bills.
Cwmman, buddai, cerwŷn. A fat, alſo a churn.
Cwmpas). A circle, alſo a pair of compaſſes.
Cwmmwd. A ſubdiviſion in a county called a Hundred.
Cwndid, cân. A ſong, a tune.
Cwnnu, codi, cychwyn. To riſe, to begin to ſtir.
Cwnſallt, pais yr arwŷddfarch. A coat-armour, a coat of arms.
Cwppwl tŷ. The raſter of a building.
Cwplyſu). To joyn or couple together.
Cwrr. The very edge or ſide of a thing.
Cwrel), maen gwerth-fawr o liw côch. A coral.
Cwrrian. To crock down as men do when they do their need under a hedge.
Cwrrwm, gŵŷriad, crymmiad. A crockedneſs, a lumpiſh ſhape.
Cwrs). A courſe, method, or order.
Cwrſi, cap lliain merch. A coif.
Cwrſi llaw, lliain ſychu trwŷn. A handkerchief.
Cwrwgl, bôt pyſgodwr a wnaed o groen ceffyl a gwîail. A fiſhers boat made of twigs and a horſe-hide.
Cwtt môch, cutt môch. A hogs ſlie.
Cwtt, briwſin, briwsîonnyn. A crum, or a little piece.
Cwympod, codymau. A downfall, a deſcent.
Cwŷn, cywŷnnu, cyfodi, cychwyn. To ariſe, to begin to ſtir.
Cŵŷn, achwyn. A complaint, lamentation; alſo an action, cauſe, accuſation, a proceſs.
Cwyno. To commence a ſuit of law, to complain.
Cwŷnfan, cwynofain. To lament, grieve, or complain.

div.head: CY.
div.p: Cychwardd, chwerthin, neu gwenu. To laugh or ſmile.
Cychwedl, cyd-chwedl. A diſcourſe, a narration, ata'c.
Cŷdio. To joyn or couple together.
Cydcam, chwarae, gwawdio. To play, to jeſt, to mock.
Cydcerdd, cŷd-ſeiniad, cyttundeb cerdd. Symphonie, concent in muſick.
Cydrâdd, or ûn Râdd. Equal, of the ſame degree or dignity.
Cydrychiol, peſennol, yngŵŷdd. Preſent or before the face.
Cydrycholder, gwŷdd llygaid, blaen wyneb. Preſence.
Cydwedd, cyttal, cŷd gynaliad. Joyned in life, as man and wife.
Cydweddu, cŷd guttal. To joyn in life, as man and wife.
Cydwledd, cŷd-wlêd. A joynt. feaſt or banquet.
Cydŵr, a fo yn gyfranog ag arall. A partner.
Cyfaddawd, cyfammod. A league, a covenant.
Cyfair, cyfer o dir. An aker or an acre of land.
Cyfalhâu, cyhafalhau, cyfalle, tebygu. To liken, compare, reſemble.
Cyfamſer. The mean time, the mean while, the interim of time.
Cyfannedd, yn waſtad, yn waſdadol. Continually.
Cyfanneddu, trigo, aros. To dwell or inhabit.
Cyfannu, gwneuthur yn gyfa. To make whole.
Cyfanſodd, goſodiad ynghŷd, cyttundeb. A compoſition.
Cyfanſoddi, goſod yn'r unlle, goſod ynghŷd. To compoſe or compile.
Cyfar, cyfariaeth, cyfarettri, cyfaru, Cyd-lafurio tîr. Plowing or tilling together.
Cyfarch, gwneuthur i un fyned, neu wneuthyr peth heb yn waetha iddo. Compel or force.
Cyfarch gwell, bŷd tâ i chwi, dŷdd dâ i chwi▪ &c. To ſalute. or greet one.
Cyfarchafael, cyrchafael, dyrchafael, mynediad i fynu. Aſcenſion.
Cyfarfod. To meet, alſo a meeting.
Cyfartal, cyſtal. Equal, or as good.
Cyfartalu, talu adre'r cyffelib. To retaliate, or repay like for like.
Cyfaru, aredig yn yr un tîr. To plough together.

Cyfarwar, cyſſon, cyttûn, cydſeiniad.
Conſonant, meet, agreeable.
Cyfarwas, ymrafael, ymddadl. Strife, debate, diſputation.
Cyfarwydd neu prŷ'r gyfarwŷdd. The glow-worm.
Cyfarwyddŵr, Hyfforddiŵr. A guide, a conduct, a directer, an inſtructer.
Cyfarwŷneb, or tu arall, gwrthwyneb. Contrariwiſe, on the other hand.
Cyfarwŷre, codi, canmol, ardderchu. To ariſe, to aſcend, exalt, alſo to praiſe.
Cyfarwys, Rhôdd neu ddawn or crefyddol ſwyniant. A gift properly beſtowed for religious uſe.
Cyfaryſtlys, ar yſtlys. On the ſide, ſideways.
Cyfebr, cyfeb. To be with young.
Cyfebru, cyfebu. To conceive properly to beaſt.
Cyfedd, gwlêdd. A feaſt, a banquet.
Cyfeddach, gwlêdda. A banquetting or feaſting.
Cyfedliw, edliw, goraf. n, lliwied. To grudge, to upbraid.
Cyfedmŷg, edmŷg, urddas, anrhydedd. Honour, glory.
Cyfeiedd, cyfeiaeth, helbul, angen. Trouble, want or neceſſity.
Cyfenw, yr enw a ganlyn o oes i oes, megis wynn, llwŷd, &c. A ſirname.
Cyfer, neu gyferbyn. Over againſt, oppoſite.
Cyfer o dir. An acre of land.
Cyferchydd, un yn erchi dŷdd dâ. A ſaluter, one that greets or bids Good morrow.
Cyferig, beichiog, cyfeb, cyflo. To be with young.
Cyfeſgar, gelŷn. An adverſary, an enemy.
Cyfieuaeth, trofa geiriau. A derivation of words, a conjugation.
Cyfhau, gwneuthur yn gyfa. To make whole.
Cyfiaith, Jaith hysbŷs. The vulgar or common language.
Cyfiaithu, troi pêthau o'r naill Jaith ir llall. To interpret, or tranſlate out of one language into another.
Cyfieithydd, yr hwn a drotho beth o'r naill Jaith i'r llall. An Interpreter, or Tranſlator of books.
Cyfiaw, • dihenyddu, cyfiowni, gwaſtadhàu. To execute, to bring to paſs.
Cyfladd, addas, cynmwys, gweddol. Fit, meet, convenient.
Cyflafaredd, ymgyfarfod i wneuthur heddwch. A meeting to make peace.
Cyfleu. To place, to ſet a thing in its place, to regulate.
Cyfled, cyn lletted. As broad, of equal breadth.
Cyfledu, gwneuthur o'r un llêd. To make of equal breadth.
Cyfliw, or un lliw. Of the ſame colour.
Cyfloi. To take bull or become with calf.
Cyfludd, lleſtair, rhwŷſtro. To incumber, hinder or diſturb.
Digyflŷdd, yn rhŷdd oddiwrth bôb rhwŷſtr. Free from all incumbrances.
Cyfluŷdd, llu o wŷr rhyfel, mintau. An army.
Cyflwg, llŵg, amlwg. Clear, very viſible.
Cyflychwŷr, dechreunos. The dusk of the evening.
Cyfluedd, cyfleuſdra. A conveniency, an opportunity.
Cyfnerth, cyfnerthi, cryfder, nerth. Firmneſs, ſtrength.
Cyfnewidwriaeth. An exchange of one for another.
Cyfnifer, cynnifer, cynaint rhyfedi. As many, alſo even or not odds.
Cyfniferawg, o 'run faint, or un rhî. Of an even number.
Cyfnod, yr amſer (pwyntiedig). The time appointed.
Cyfoed, cywoed, or un oed. Of the ſame age.
Cyfoethogi. To enrich, to grow wealthy.
Cyfogi. To vomit, to caſt up.
Cyfòr, cyforiog, tuagat y tîr. Towards the ſhore-ſide.
Cyforio, dyfod i dir. To come a ſhore.
Cyfrannu. To divide equally or juſtly.
Cyfrannog. To partake or have a ſhare.
Cyfrangc, ymladdfa, ymgyrch, ymgyfarfod gelynion. A battle, a conflict, a skirmiſh.
Cyfrdoſt, (tôſt) iawn, tra llŷm. Very ſharp or vehement.
Cyfrdriſt, triſt iawn. very ſad, heavy or mournful.
Cyfre, cyfref, cymmaint. As much, as big.
Cyfreu, argyfren, cynhyſgaeth. A dowry or portion.
Cyfred, rhedeg rhedfa unghud. Running a race together.
Cyfreſtru, rhwymo ynghyd. To tie or knit.
Cyfrgain, têg iawn, hardd iawn. Very fair, beautiful.
Cyfrgolli, myned ar goll. To periſh, to be loſt.
Cifrif, neu rhîf. A number, alſo a computation, accompts.
Cyfrif, neu rhîfo. To number, compute, to caſt accompts.
Cyfrifol. Of good eſteem or reputation.
Cyfrin, euog, cuddiedig. Guilty, alſo ſecret.
Cyfrinachu To talk of ſecret things, alſo to conceal.
Cyfryngwr, dymunwr dros un arall. A mediator, an interceſſor.
Cyfryngu, dymuno dros un arall. To mediate, to intercede.
Cyfrwŷdd, rhwydd iawn, llwyddiannus. Expedite, proſperous.
Crfrwyſo. To grow crafty or cunning.
Cyfurdd, cyſtadl, or un râdd. Equal, of the ſame degree.
Cyfurddawr, o uchel râdd. Honourable, or of the higheſt order.
Cyfwlch, addas, cymwys, cyfleuŷs. Convenient, fit.
Cyfwrdd, cyhwrdd, cyffwrdd, teimlo, ymgyfarfod. To touch, alſo to meet together.
Cyfwyrain, derchafu, codi. To ariſe or aſcend.
Cyfylfin, a'r un fath bigau. Having the bill or nib alike.
Cyfyngu. To ſtraiten or make narrow.
Cyfyſgar, cyfeſgar, gelŷn. An enemy. an adverſary.
Cŷff. The trunk of a tree.
Cyffeithio, mwŷdo lledr. To ſoften leather with a liquor.

Cyffin, terfyn yn gwhanu
gwledydd neu diroedd. A Confine, a bound or mere to divide countrys or lands.
Cyffoden, puttain. A concubine, a harlot.
Cyffred, ymwaſgu, cyfleidio, cyrheuddŷd. To embrace, alſo to contain.
Cyffŷr, cyffyriau, cer, offer. Tools or inſtruments, alſo ingredients, compounds, medicines.
Cyhafal, yn debig iawn, yr un modd. Very like, in all things alike.
Cyhafalhàu, cyfalhau, tebygu. To liken, to reſemble.
Cyhedd, cyhoedd, ar oſdeg. Open, publick.
Cyhoedd, ar gyhoedd, ar oſdeg. Publickly, openly.
Cyhoeddi, rhoddi allan ar oſdeg. To publiſh.
Cyhwfan. To pant, ſhake or throb.
Cyhwrdd, cywrdd, cwrdd, cyffwrdd, cyfarfod. To touch, to meet.
Cyhŷd, cŷd, or un hŷd. As long, of equal length.
Cyhydedd, cyhŷd dŷdd ar nôs, or un hŷd. Of equal longitude, equinoctial, alſo twiſted together as twiſted thread.
Cyhydu, cyhydeddu, gwneuthur or un hŷd, hefŷd cyrdeddu. To make of the ſame length; alſo to twiſt together.
Cyhydreg. cadw (cwmpeini,) cyſwllt, cydio. To keep company, to joyn, to copulate.
Cyhŷr, rhŷw ran o gnawd dŷn, hefŷd llygoden fechan. A muſcle; alſo a little mouſe.
Cylafareddwr, gwneuthurwr tangnheddŷf, ymddiddanwr. A peace maker, a reconciler; alſo a communicator.
Cŷlch neu cŷlch lleſtr. A hoop.
Cylionen, cylion, gwŷbedŷn. A flie, a gnat.

Cylion paradwŷs, màth ar chwilod diſgiaer fel aur, ſy 'n magu mewn pren on, ac a arferir i godi twnn croen neu chwyſigennau. A kind of beettles or horſesflies ſhining like gold, and breeds in the tops of aſh-trees, and are uſed to raiſe bliſters.
Cylŷs, beius, ar fai, euog. Culpeble, blameable.
Cylla. The paunch of the belly.
Cyllaeth, dolur, gofid. Pain, grief, ſorrow, torment.
Cyllagwſt, dolur o fol. Pain or griping in the belly.
Cŷlleſtrig, cylleſtrigawl, caled fel calleſtr. Flinty.
Cyllid, dyfodiad yn ôl, cynnŷdd. A return, an increaſe.
Cymmaint, cymmain. So many, ſo much, as much, ſo great.
Cymmalu, rhoddi cymmal yn ei lê. To ſet a joynt, to joynt.
Cymmanfa, cynnulleidfa. A congregation, an aſſembly.
Cymmhedroli, cymmheſuro. To proportion, to adapt, to temperate.
Cymmherfedd, y canol. The middle, the centre.
Cymmelrhi, terfyſg, cyffro. A tumult, a diſturbance.
Cymmell. To profer, alſo to compel.
Cymmhennu, addurno 'r ymadrodd. To adorn the ſpeech.

Cymmhes, cymmheſurwŷdd, cymmhedroldeb, cymhwŷſdra.
Mediocrity, a juſt proportion.
Cymmheſur. According to deſert, meet, fit.
Cymmheſurwŷdd, cymhwŷſtra, y rhŷn a waſanaetho. Mediocrity, what is enough.
Cymmheſuro. To make meet or fit.
Cymmoni, plygu. To bend, to fold.
Cymmradwŷ, wedi ei lygrŷ, wedi ddiftrywio. Subverted, deſtroyed, corrupted, alſo currant or paſſable.
Cymmrawu, brawychu To be afraid or terrified, alſo to fright or ſcare.
Cymmrwd, (morter) o galch a phrîdd. Morter made of lime, &c.
Cymmrwŷn, trîſt, hefŷd brwŷn. Ruſhes, alſo ſadneſs or ſorrow.
Cymmrŷd, cymmerŷd. To take, to receive.
Cymmbrŷd, mor brydferthol, cyn degced. Of ſuch a form, of equal beauty, ſo beautiful.
Cymmwd, cwmmwd. A Hundred or diviſions in a county ſo called.
Cymmwŷo, blino, trallodi. To afflict, to trouble, to vex.
Cymmwŷll, crybwŷll, Sôn. To make mention.
Cymmwŷnas. A good turn, a kindneſs.
Cymmwŷn, cyfeb. A mare or yew with young is called ſo.
Cymmynu. To cut, hew, or chop with a hatchet.
Cymmynai, bwŷall. A hatchet, an ax.
Cymmynad, cymmynŵr. He that ſtrikes with an hatchet, a hewer of wood.
Cymmynnawg, dyrnod bwŷall. The ſtroke of an ax or hatchet.
Cymmŷn, yr hyn a roddo dŷn i eraill cŷn ei farw. A legacy.
Cymmynnug, gwneuthur ewŷllŷs neu lythŷr Cymmŷn. To bequeath or give legacies.
Cymmyrred, cymmyrredd, cymmyrraeth. Dignity, honour, eſteem, acceptation; alſo a taking upon.
Cymmyrreddus, balch, hefyd cymmeradwy. Proud, arrogant, alſo acceptable, grateful.
Cynio. To wedge or faſten with a wedge.
Cyn, o flaen, yn gynt. Before, ſooner.
Cynanu, ſiarad, ymgommio, hefŷd fel a digwyddodd. To ſpeak, to diſcourſe; alſo as it hapned.
Cyndrychiol, cydrychiol, preſennol, wŷneb yn wŷneb. Preſent, or face to face.
Cynddail, y dail cyntaf The leaves of the firſt ſpring.
Cynddelw, (y pattrwm) cyntaf. The firſt pattern.
Cynddŷdd, torriad y dŷdd, y dydd gynt. The break of day; alſo former days.
Cynferthŷr, y merthŷr cyntaf, Sef St. Stephen. The firſt Martyr St. Stephen.
Cynflith, blaenion llaeth. The firſt milk.
Cynfŷd, y bŷd sgynt, yr hên Amſer. The old time, the former time.
Cynffonnog. Having a tail, or a long tail.
Cyngaſ, cacci. inwcci. The general names of burs, a clotbur; alſo any thing that is friſled like burs.
Cynghafog, megis caccimwcci. Of or like a bur.
Cynghanedd. Harmony, concent, true meeters in verſe.
Cynghaneddu, cyſon ganu. To ſing tuneably, to rime properly.
Cynghaws, Achos, cwŷn A cauſe, a Law ſuit, an Accuſation, a Preceſs.
Cynghawſedd, cyhuddiad. An Accuſation, Proceſs, a Law ſuit.
Cynghellawr, penna uſtus ynghyfreth cyfiawnder. A Chancellour.
Cynghori. To counſel, advice or exhort.
Cynghorfynnû, cenfigennu. To envy, to emulate.
Cyngrabad, dedwŷddwch, tynged ddâ. Happineſs, good fortune.
Cyngrair, cyfammod. A league, a covenant.
Cyngrod, clinhiadur. The blades or wheel to winde thread upon.
Cyngroesfforedd, croesffordd A place where two wayes meet.
Cyngwl, y pechod cyntaf, y pechadur cyntaf. The firſt ſin, the firſt ſinner.
Cyngwyſtl, gwyſtl. A pledge, a pawn.
Cyngydio, oedi. To defer, to delay.
Cynhaig, cynherig. To be proud as a bitch is wont to be.
Cynhelw, cynnal, attal. To uphold, ſupport, or prop.
Cynhelwŷ, cynnal, attal. To bear up or ſupport.
Cynhenid, heb eni, newŷdd eni. Unborn, newly born.
Cynhwynol, breiniol, rhŷdd, anian, (naturiol). Imperial, free, natural; but is now token for ſtark mad.
Cynired, cyrchu, mynŷch gyrchu, mynŷch dramwŷ. To frequent, to go often.
Cynllaeth, y llaeth cyntaf. The firſt milk.
Cynllwŷn, ymlid, calŷn ar ôl. To purſue; alſo a purſuing.
Cynllyfan. A leading-ſtring, commonly for grey-hounds.
Cynnadl, ymddadleu, ymreſymmiad. A diſputation, a diſcourſe.
Cynnatla, ymddadlu, ymrſymmu. To diſſcourſe, to diſpute.
Cynnal. To prop, uphold or bear up.
Cynheliaeth, cynhaliad i fynu. Subſiſtence, ſuſtaination.
Cynnarwch, amſer cymmwys, cyfleuuſtra. Time convenient, good ſeaſon, opportunity.
Cyfnaſedd, anrheg. A preſent or free gift.
Cynneddſ, dull, môdd, arfer. A quality, cuſtom.
Cynnelw, attal, attreg, cynnal. To uphold.
Cynnhewi, attal ei dafod. To hold ones peace.
Cynnhewydd, gŵr diſtaw. A ſilent man.
Cynnif, gofid, cyfyngder, cledi. Trouble, adverſity.
Cynnifiad, cynnifiwr, treiſiŵr, cribddeiliŵr, gormeſŵr, gorthrechŵr. An extortioner, an oppreſſour.
Cynnifer, cymmaint rhifedi, yr un rhifedi. As many, the ſame number.
Cynniweir, mynŷch arferu, mynŷch dramwŷ. To frequent.
Cynnog, cynnogn, prîf ddyledŵr, penna dyledŵr. The principal debtor.
Cynnogni, gwneuthur ei hun yn ddyledŵr. To make himſelf debtor.
Cynnor, cyntor, yſtluſ-bôſt drŵs. The poſt that the door ſhuts to.
Cynnhordŷ, porth bychan, (Ports) drŵs. A porch or entrance to a door.
Cynnhorawr, porthor. A Door-keeper or Porter.
Cynnud, coed iw lloſgi. Wood fuell.
Cynnutta, hel coed, coetta. To gather wood.
Cynnuttai, cynnuttŵr, heliwr coed. A wood-gatherer.
Cynnuttwr, coettwr, un yn caſglu coed. A wood-gatherer.
Cynnwll, hîn deg, wŷbr eglur. Fair weather, a clear skie, without clouds.
Cynnwŷs, dal yn do, genni ynddo. To contain.
Cynnwŷs, gadel i beth fôd. To ſuffer one to be or to do ſo and ſo.
Cynnwŷs, bychan, cryno. Compact, of little ſubſtance.
Cynnyddweſt, ſiecced dŷn bychan. A childs coat.
Cynnygn, gwrthwŷnebwr, gelŷn. An adverſary, an enemy.
Cynnyſgaeddu. To endow, to give a dowry or Portion.
Cynoſod, yr ymgyrch cyntaf, y rhuthr cyntaf, yr ymgyfarfod cyntaf. The firſt aſſault or onſet.
Cynrhan, y rhan gyntaf ar fwŷaf. The firſt and greateſt part.
Cynrhawni. To breed worms or maggots.
Cŷnt, gŷnt, yr amſer a aeth heibio. In times paſt, formerly, before.
Cyntaf. The firſt, alſo the ſwifteſt.
Cyntor, cynnor, vſtlŷs-boſt drŵs. The poſt that the door ſhuts to.
Cyntorſ, y fyddin gyntaf, y dyrfa gyntaf. The firſt army.
Cynwân, y gwendid cyntaf. The firſt weakneſs.
Cynwe, gwe. A web of cloth.
Cynwŷdd, tîr gŵŷdd pan ardder gyntaf. Land ploughed the firſt time.
Cynŵŷn, cynfwŷn, cynffrwŷth, y ffrwŷth neu 'r toraeth cyntaf. The firſt fruits or increaſe.
Cynwŷre, cyfodiad. A riſing, or firſt appearance.
Cynwyrain, cyfodi. To riſe, to ſpring up.
Cynyddiaeth, ſwŷdd y cynŷdd, hêla. The office of a huntſman, hunting.
Cyrbwŷll, crybwŷll, sôn, mynegi. To make mention, to declare.
Cŷrdd, Cerddau, canhiadau. Muſick, ſongs, ſonnets.
Cyrf, corf, corph The body or cheſt.
Cyrfŷll, corph bychan. A little body.
Cyrniad, ceirniad, chwŷthwr corn. A blower in a born, a Cornet.
Cyrraedd, cyrredd, cyrrhaedded, cyrrhaeddud To reach or touch any thing, to attain.
Cyrrith, cynnil, cybyddedd. Sparing, niggard, covetous.
Cysbyddwn, cydfyddwn, cyttunwn. Let us agree or be at peace.
Cyſſegr, bendigaid-lê. A conſecrated place, a ſanctuary.
Cyſſegr-ladrad, lladrad eglwŷs. Sacriledge or Church-robbery.
Cyſſondeb. A concent in muſick, agreement in ſound.
Cyſſul, cyngor, cynghori. Counſel, advice, alſo to counſel.
Cyſſuro. To comfort, to refreſh, to recreate.
Cyſſwllt, goſodiad ynghud. A conjunction, a joyning, a coupling.
Cyſſylltu, goſod ynghud. To joyn together.
Cyſſwyn, cyttundeb. A conſent, accord or agreement, confederacy.
Cyſſymmaith, goſymmaith, bwŷd a diod. Victuals, food.
Cyſgogi, yſgwŷd, ſiglo. To quake or ſhake.
Cyſgu. A ſleep, alſo to ſleep.
Cyſtadlu, cyftelybu. To equalize, to compare.
Cyſtlynu, cyfathrachu. To joyn in alliance.
Cyſtuddio, blino, (trwhlio). To afflict, to vex, or trouble.
Cyſtwŷo, ceryddu. To chaſten, to puniſh, to rebuke.
Cŷtgam, cellwair. To jeſt or joke.
Cythrudd, cythruddiad. Horrour, trouble of mind.
Cythruddo. To diſturb or trouble, to be diſturbed or provoked.
Cythrwfl, cyffro. A conmetion, a tumult.
Cythryblu, cyffroi, brawychu. To diſturb, trouble or afflict.
Cyttir, tir yn perthyn i amriw. A common, alſo lands belonging to ſeveral.
Cyttirogion, y rhai a fo'n rhanog o dir, hefŷd cymydogion. Partners in land, alſo neighbours.
Cyttref, or un drêf. Of the ſame city or town.

Cyttŷaeth, teuluedd, cymdeithas tŷ. Familiarity,
fellowſhip in one houſe.
Cyttŷn, yn cŷd-tynnu, o unfrŷd. Drawing together, of one mind.
Cyttynnu, tynnu i'r un ffordd. To draw together, to conſent.
Cŷw. A chicken, a young fowl.
Cywaethlu, ymryſon. To ſtrive or contend.
Cywair, wedi dacclu neu drefnuſo. Repair'd, amend.
Cyweirio. To repair, to amend, to dreſs, alſo to geld.
Cyweirgorn, peth idaro tannau wrth ganu. A quill, or any ſuch thing to ſtrike on the ſtrings of muſick.
Gyweithŷdd, tyrfa, llu, mintau. A troop or company.
Cywerthŷdd, (pris,) gwerth. A price or value.
Cyweſlach, cŷd-cnawd, priodas. Carnal copulation, wedlock.
Cywethl, cerŷdd, ſenn. A chiding. blaming, or rebuking.
Cywilyddio. To ſhame, or diſgrace one, alſo to be aſhamed.
Cywiro. To perform ones promiſe, alſo to rectifie.
Cywlâd, or un wlâd: Countrymen, of the ſame country.
Cywleiddiadon, rhai or un wlâd. Perſons of the ſame country.
Cywreinio, gwneuthur pêth yn gelfŷddgar. To do a thing skilfully.
Cywryſedd, cyfryſedd, crwyſedd, ymryſſon. Strife, contention.
Cywŷdd. A verſe of ſeven ſyllable, a ſorrowful ſong.
Cywŷddaid, cànwr cywŷddau. The maker or ſinger of Elegies, &c.
Cywŷddoliaeth. The art of making Elegies, &c.

div.head: CH.
div.p: CHwâ, Awel. A blaſt or gale of wind.
Chwai, buan, pryſur, cyflym. Quick, haſty, nimble.
Chwaith, blâs. The ſenſe of Taſting, a taſte.
Chwaithu, chwaethu, profi blâs. To taſte.
Chwalu. To ſpread, to ſtrow, diſperſe, to ſcatter.
Chwant. Hunger, appetite, alſo luſt, covetouſneſs.
Chwrel, tryfer, piccell. A dart, a javelin.
Chwareŷdd, chwrŷdd. A gunſter, a player.
Chwareŷddiaeth, chwaryddiaeth. A play, ſport or paſtime, gaining.
Chwarien, Araf, meddal. Mild, ſoft, ſlow.
Chwarienu, arafu. To wax mild or ſoft, to ſlaken ones pace.
Chwarren. A round riſing or ſwelling in the fleſh like a ball, or an apple.
Chwedl. A fable, a tale, a ſtory.
Chwegr, mam ynghyfraith. A mother-in-law, a ſtep-mother.
Chwegrwn, Tâd ynghyfraith. A father-in-law, a ſtep-father.
Chwerig, gwêdd chwerig, (anterliwt). Entherlute, a ſtage play.
Chwerfan, chwarfan. A winch for a ſpindle, a pulley.
Chwerthin gwatwor. To meek, to deride.

Chwerthinog, gwatwarue
That laugheth much, full of mocking and flouting.
Chweu, llymhau, chwiblo. To wax tart, ſour or ſharp.
Chwiban, chwibaniad. A whiſtling with the mouth.
Chwibanogl, chwibenygl, chwibianog. A pipe or flute.
Chwibanogl fynudd, ydêrŷn a elwir fellu, ag weithiau cylfin hir. A bird called Curlew.
Chwibl, Sûr, tôſt, llymm. Sour, ſharp, biting.
Chwiblo. To grow ſharp or ſour.
Chwifiwr, rhodiennwr. A vagabond, a wanderer.
Chwilenna, chwiltath, chwilotta. To pilfer, or ſteal.
Chwiliog, un ag yſprŷd drŵg ynddo. A man poſſeſſed with a deviliſh ſpirit of propheſying.
Chwilioges, merch âg yſpryd drŵg ynddi. A woman poſſeſſed with a deviliſh ſpirit of propheſying.
Chwiliores, cyccynen fawr. A great waſp called a hornet.
Chwimio, rhodienna. To wander, to go aſtray.
Chwimp, croŷw, llyfn Freſh, ſmooth, poliſhed.
Chwiog, bara tiſen, bara calan. A ſweet cake-bread.
Chwiſtrell, chwibianogl, (pibell). A flute, a pipe, a recorder
Chwiſtrellu, chwarae ar bibell. To pipe, to play upon the recorder.
Chwitho, dychrynu. To tremble with fear.
Chwithrwd, chwibanu. To hiſs, to whiſtle.
Chwŷd, chwdiad. A vomit, a ſpuing.
Chwŷdu, chwdu. To vomit, to ſpue.
Chwÿd-awŷr, pydredd yn ſyrthio or awŷr. A putrified matter that falls from the Stars.
Chwŷdredd, treulio, curio. To languiſh or conſume away.
Chwŷl, trô, treigl. A change, a turn.
Chwŷn a chwŷn, feſawl ychydig, o dippin i dippin. By little and little, by leaſure.
Chwŷrnu, chwrnu. To ſnarle like a dog, alſo to ſnore.
Chwŷſigen. A bladder, alſo a wheal or bliſter.
Chwŷſigennog. That has bliſters, wheals or puſhes.
Chwŷth, chwŷthad. A blaſt or gale of wind.

div.head: DA.
div.p: Dâ neu daoedd. Goods, or cattle.
Dadferu, troi'n ôl, talu 'n ôl. To return, to reſtore.
Dadleu. To contend, to argue, to diſpute.
Dadlaith, dadmeru, meirioli. To thaw that which is frozen.
Dadmer, meiriol. A thaw, a diſſolving.
Dadolwch, iawn am ddrŵg. Satisfaction for an evil committed.

Dadolychu, gwneuthur iawn ir hriwedig. To ſatisfy the
offended, or to be reconciled.
Dadwrdd. To prate, or make a noiſe.
Daearu, claddu. To bury, to lay in the earth.
Daerawd, daered, hên ddefod a delir dros y meirw. Funeral Rites and Ceremonies, a mortuary pay'd for the dead.
Daeth. He came, it came, ſhe came.
Dafnu, defnynnu. To drop, to diſtill.
Defni. The dropping of the eavs, the dropping that falls through the roof of a houſe.
Dafn, yr ydafedd ar wennol y gwŷdd. The threads on the ſhuttle.
Daigr, degrŷn, deigrŷn. A tear in weeping.
Deigrynnu, diferu fel dagru. To drop like tears, to weep tears.
Dail. Leaves of trees, or herbs.
Dalen. A leaf of a book.
Deilen. A leaf of a tree or herb.
Deilio. To bear leaves, to wax green-bowed.
Dallu. To wax blind, to blind.
Damblygu, plugu o gwmpas. To fold about, to wrap about.
Damchwain, digwŷddiad. An accident, or event.
Damwain, digwŷdd. A hapning, a chance, an accident.
Damwainio, digwŷddo. To happen or fall out.
Dandde, ennŷnfa, tragwrês, peothfa, dolur poethlud. An inflammation.

Dangoſeg, arwydd i ddangos, yr eurfaen a braw 'r aur,
Cynhwyſiad llyfr neu ran o hono. A token to ſhew, a touch-ſtone to try gold and ſilver, alſo a Table or Contents of a Book.
Dannod, lliwied To upbraid, an upbraiding.
Dannodiaeth, gorafyn. An exprobation, or upbraiding.
Danſang, ſathru, mathru. To tread or trample.
Deintws, daint bychan. A little tooth.
Deintio, danheddu, brathu. To bite, to faſten with the teeth.
Danŷs, gafr ddânas, ewig lwŷd. A fallow-deer.
Darbod, arlwŷo, gofalu. To provide, to take care.
Darogan. A Propheſie, alſo an Oracle.
Daroſtwng, goſdwng. To ſubdue, or bring under.
Darren, gogyſgu, heppian. To nod, to ſleep.
Darſtain, attebleiſio. To eccho or ſound again.
Dart), ſaeth. A dart, an arrow.
Darwein, ffrydio allan, llifo. To flow or run out.
Darymred, rhodio o amgŷlch. To walk about.
Dâs A rick of corn or hay.
Daſwrn, das. A rick of corn or hay, &c.
Daſyrnu, daſylu, daſu. To make into ricks.
Datgan, mynegŷ. To declare, alſo to ſing other mens Verſes.
Daſceiniad, datcanwr, canwr, mynegwr. A ſinger, a ſpeaker.
Dattod. To untie, or untwiſt, alſo to rip.
Daw, dawf, màb ynghyfraith. A ſon-in-law.
Dawn, rhôdd. A gift, a reward.
Donniog, yr hwn ſy gwedi cael rhoddiad. That has gifts.
Dawr, tawr, mae 'n rhaid, ef a weddau. it behoves.

div.head: DE.
div.p: Dean, pen ar ddég. A captain over ten, alſo a Dean.
Dear, ſŷn, rhuad. A ſound, a noiſe, a roaring.
Deau, dehau. Right; alſo the South.
Dechu, techu, llechu. To lie hid.
Dedrŷd, tŷb, meddwl, barn. A verdict, a ſentence.
Deddf, cyfreth. A Law, a Statute.
Defnŷdd, denfŷdd, deunŷdd. Matter or ſtuff wherewith any thing is made; alſo an uſe to put things to.
Defnyddio. To prepare any matter, to cut out.
Defod, arfer. A manner, a cuſtom.
Deheubartheg, Jaith pobl y dehau. A Southern Language.
Deheuberthig, a berthŷn ir denhau. Belonging to the South.
Deigr, deigrŷn, degrŷn. A tear or weeping-drop.
Deilw, egwŷd. The ſmalleſt part of the leg, called the lock of the leg or foot.
Deilliaw, myned allan, dyfod allan, dyfod oddiwrth. To proceed from.
Deincod, dincod. The core of an apple, &c.
Deintgrŷd, deintcrŷd, crynfa ar y dannedd. The ſhaking of the teeth.
Deisŷf, deiſyfiad, dymuniad. A A petition, an intreaty.
Deiſyfu, dymuno. To petition, to deſire, to beſeech.
Del, anynad, drygnaws. Froward, arrogant, ſawcy, ſullen.
Delor, aderŷn a elwir weithiau cymmynwr y Coed. A bird called a Wood-pecker, or an Eat-bee.
Delwi, glaſu, colli lliw, To wax pale or wan.
Delwad, yſtum, ſut, môdd. Information, form, faſhion.
Delltennu, hollti dellt. To make into ſplinters.
Dengŷn, tauogaidd, iddewwaidd. Ruſtick, inhumane, barbarous.
Deol, dehol, alldudaeth, herwriaeth, alltudiaeth. Baniſhment.
Deolwr, yr hwn ſy 'n gwahardd ei wlâd i un arall. He that baniſheth.
Deon), (Diacon), dengwriad, pen ar ddêg. A Dean.
Deor, cynnŷrch, magu cywion. To hatch, to breed.
Dera, y ddera, Satan, diaſol. The Devil.
Derbi, derfi, budd, elw, ynnill. Gain, profit.
Derllŷdd, derllyddu, dyrllŷdd, dyrlleuŷdd, darllennŷdd, darllennwr. A Reader.
Derwreinin, march-wreinin. A letter, a wring-worm.
Derwŷddon, gwŷr doethion, daroganwŷr. Wiſemen, Prophets.
Derŷnt, darfuant. They are periſhed, they are done and ended.
Deſtl, deſtlus, glàn, danteiddiol. Clean, delicate.
Dethol, dewis, deffol. To chooſe, to elect.
Deubŷdd, fe fŷdd, fe ddaw. It will be, it will come to paſs.
Deupo, dêlo, byddo. As it comes.

div.head: DI.
div.p: Diachar, anhŷgar, digâr, câs, anhawddgar. Not amiable, odious.
Diachor, o faint canolig. Of a middle ſize or ſtature.
Diafl, diafol, diafwl, diawl, The devil.
Diafrddwl, heb ofal, heb driſtrwch. Without care or ſorrow.
Dialbren, prenddiodef. A gibbet, a gallows.
Dialechdid, celfyddŷd ymreſymmu. The Art of Logick.
Dianaf, heb anaf, heb dwnn. Without maim or lameleſs, without blemiſh.
Diangc. To evade, to ſhun, to eſcape.
Diannod, yn ddioed, yn ddiattreg, yn y man. Which is not delayed, preſently, forthwith.
Diar, sŵn, trŵſt, hefyd ſynio. A noiſe, to make a noiſe.
Diarchennu, tynnu eſgidiau. To put off ones ſhoos.
Diaffordd, allan or ffordd. Out of the way.
Diargyffwr, diofnog. Nothing afraid, without fear, fearleſs.
Diargywedd, gwirion, difai, di euog. Innocent, blameleſs.
Diaſpad, sŵn, trŵſt, dwndwr. A noiſe, a clamour.
Diaſpedain, dolefain, crochlefain. To ſhout very loud.
Dibara, darfodedig, trangcedig. Tranſitory, that which paſſeth away, ſhort, not durable.
Diben, dibendod. An end, a concluſion.
Dible. The daggling or daggings of ones garment.
Diblygu, Dirwŷſtro, egluro. To unfold, to make clear.
Diccra. That eats but little, puny.
Dichell. Craft, cunning, a cunning trick.
Dichlais, clais du. Black and blue as made by a ſtroke.
Dichlŷn, ymogelgar. Cautious, wary, alſo nimble.
Dichon, dichŷn, gallu. To be able.
Dichwêl, heb newidio, anghyfnewidiol. Without change, immutable.
Dichwen, dichwain, damwain, digwŷdd. Event, chance, accident.
Didach, llechu, ymguddio. To lie in wait, to lie hid.
Didachwr, llechwr. A lurker, one lying in wait.
Didawl, dibaid, didorr, diorffwŷs. Inceſſant, unwearied.
Diden. A breaſt, a pap, a dug.
Didràs, eſtron. Nothing a kin, nothing related.
Didro, bai, hefyd cam-gymmerŷd. An errour, alſo to miſtake or err.
Didrŷf, bŷwoliaeth grefyddol. A Monaſtick life.
Didryfwr, meudwŷ, ancr, dŷn yn bŷw yn unig er mwŷn duwioldeb. An Hermit.
Didŷo, ſymmŷd, cymmeryd tŷ un oddi uwch ei benn. To take ones houſe from of his head, to remove.
Didudŷdd, gwneuthur uny alltud neu herwr. The making of one an exile.
Diddanu. To make merry, to divert.
Diddawl, diddoli, didoli, dydoli. To ſeparate.
Diddos. Free from rain, that keeps out rain.
Diddofi. To free or ſecure from rain.
Diddym, dim, diddeunŷdd. A thing of nothing, of no uſe.
Diddymmu, gwneuthur yn ddi ddeunŷdd. To abrogate, to aboliſh.
Dieflig, diawledig, cythreulig. Deviliſh, poſſeſſed with a devil.
Dielwi, dirmygu. To deſpiſe, to vilifie.
Diemmig, difychan. Not very ſmall or little.
Dien, dihenŷdd, marwolaeth am ddyreidi. Death, Execution.
Dien, diammau, hefyd di hên. Certain, manifeſt, alſo young or not old.
Dienbŷd, diogel, gwŷn-fŷd. Secure, without dànger, happineſs.
Diennig, diymarbed. That will not ſpare.
Difelo. To amend, to correct, to make faultleſs.
Difalldrain, diniſtrio, (diſtrywio). to waſte, to deſtroy.
Difan, ofer, diffrwŷth, methiedig. Vain, fadeing, periſhing
Difanw, ofer, gwàg, hefyd diyſtyru. Vain, alſo to vilifie, to deſpiſe.
Difenwi, llaſenwi. To revile, to raile, to taunt, to nickname.
Diferu. To diſtill, to drop down by little and little.
Difiog, anwàr, an-nôf, gwŷllt. Vntamed, unbridled, wild.
Diflaen, pig gwauwffon neu arf arall. The point of a ſpear or another weapon.
Diflaſu. To make unſavoury, to wax unſavoury.
Difrifo. To be made or become grave or ſerious.
Difro, herwr, alltud. An exile, a baniſhed man or woman.
Difwŷn. di-fûdd, di-ennill, diddeunŷdd. Unprofitable, of no uſe.
Difwŷno. li-fuddio, diwŷno. To make a thing unprofitable, or of no uſe▪ to mar or ſpoil.
Difŷn, briwsŷn, briwſionŷn. A piece, a fragment, a crum.
Difynnio, torri 'n ddrylliau. To cut in pieces.
Difŷr, bŷrr, llawen. Short, alſo joyful, divertive.
Difyfgi, terfŷſg, ciwed, cynnwrf, anrhefn. A tumult, a confuſion.
Diffaith, dryſni. A deſart, a wilderneſs.
Diffaithio, anrheithio, deſtrywio. To waſte, to ſpoil.
Diffaith, drŵg. Vicious, vile, filthy, evil.
Diffoddi. To quench, to put out, to extinguiſh.
Diffwn, dyffwn, deuwn, down. Let us come.
Diffwys, ſerth. Steepy, dangerous to ſtand upon.
Digennu, tynnu cenn oddiar byſgod. To ſcale fiſh.
Digibo. To ſhell, to take off the husks.
Digliſt, màth ar glai. A kind of clay uſed for morter.
Digoni. To ſatisfy, to do enough.
Digrain, cam-gymmeriad. A miſtake, an errour.
Digronni, crowni, Cronni. To corrupt, to riſe to a head.
Digryd, di ofn, di arſwŷd. Without fear, undaunted.
Digwŷdd, digwŷddiad. An accident, an event.
Digwŷddo. To happen, to fall out.
Digyflŷdd, rhŷdd oddiwrth bôb rhwŷſtr. Free from hinderance.
Dihatru, dinoethi. To ſpoil, to ſtrip naked.
Dihenŷdd, diwedd, diben, llam ddrŵg. Death, fate, end, execution.
Dihenyddu, rhoddi i farwolaeth. To put to death, to execute.
Dihenyddwr, crogwr. A hangman, an executioner.
Diheuro, cyfiawnhau ei hun. To clear ones ſelf.
Dihewŷd, tuedd meddwl, ewŷllŷs. The affection, deſire, devotion.
Dihinedd, cafod, temheſtl. A ſhowre, a tempeſt.
Dihiren, dihirog. A wicked woman, an ill female.
Dinirŷn. A knave, a villain, a rogue.
Dihoeni. To wither as a flower, to abate in courage.
Dilachar, gwrymmus, calonnog. Stout, couragious, undaunted.
Dilechtid, celfyddŷd ymreſymmu. The Art of Logick.
Diledach, diledrŷw, Breiniol, bonheddig, ardderchog. Noble.
Diledleſ, llais neu ymadrodd eglur ddilediaeth. A clear perfect voice or language without Barbariſm.
Diledtŷb, diamn eu Void of ſuſpition or ſuppoſition.
Dilêu, diniſtrio, difetha. To blot out, to deſtroy.
Dilin, coethi, curo tan fwrthwl. To trace or beat with a hammer.
Diluw, llif mawr, cenllif, gweilgif. Deluge or great flood, Noah's flood.
Dilwfr, dilwrf, gwrol, diddîog. Valiant, not ſluggiſh.
Dilŷn, calŷn. To purſue, to follow, enſuing, to inſiſt
Dilŷth, na aller ei wrthod, cymmeradwy. Not to be refuſed, acceptable, current.
Dill, plŷg, crychni, hefŷd dull. A fold, a wrinkle, alſo a form or faſhion.
Dillwng, gillwng. To let go, to redeem.
Dinasfraint, awdurdod dinas. The Charter or Liberty of a City.
Dinaſig, dinaſaidd, a berthyno i ddinas. Pertaining to a City.
Dinaſwr, dinesŷdd, gŵr o ddinas. A Citizen.
Dinboeth, math ar aderŷn. A bird called a Red-tayl.
Dincod, dincodŷn. The cores of an apple or pear, &c.
Dincod ar ddannedd. When the teeth are ſet an edge.
Dinêu, tywallt allan. To pour out.
Dinidr, yn ddiaros, yn y man. Without delay, preſently.
Diotta. To tipple or drink often, to beg drink, alſo to feed or ſupply with drink.
Diod, dioſg. To put off, to ſtrip, or undreſs.
Dioddeu, goddeu, amcan, brŷd. A purpoſe or intent.
Dioer, ſiccrŷdd, dinam. Certainly, without doubt.
Diofrŷd, diowrŷd, llŵ. Renouncing, for ſwearing, a vow.
Diofrydu, rhoddi diowrŷd, ymwrthod. To abjure, to renounce.
Diogel, cadarn, diſiomgar, ſiccr, cadwedig. Safe, ſecure, firm.
Diogelu, gwneuthur yn gadarn. To make ſafe or ſecure.
Dioheb, diatteb, nad ellir ei atteb. Unanſwerable.
Diohir, yn ddi ymaros. Without delay.
Diol, ôl. A track, a path.
Dioſg, ymddioſg. To put off ones clothes, to undreſs, to ſtrip naked.
Di phwys, lle ſerth, lle dyrŷs. A precipice, a downfall.
Dirio, anghenu, gwaſgu ar, pwyſo ar, cymmell. To neceſſitate, to compell, to preſs, to urge.
Diriawr, cymmellwr, treiſiwr, un yn pwyſo'n galed. A conſtrainer, one that preſſeth hard.
Diriaid. Wicked, of an evil life.
Dirdra, y camwedd mwŷaf. The higheſt injury.
Dirgelu, celu, cuddio. To hide, to conceal.
Dirgeledd, dirgelwch. A ſecret, a myſtery.
Diriſglo. To pill or bark a tree.
Dirmŷg, gogan, diyſtyrwch. Contempt, deſpight, diſparagement.
Dirmygu, goganu. To deſpiſe, to ſlander, to diſparage.
Dirnad, deall, dwyn ar ddeall. To expound, to interpret, to underſtand, to unfold.
Dirper, dyleu. To owe, to deſerve.
Dirprwŷo, cyflawni yr hyn ſŷ 'n eiſiau. To ſupply the place of another.
Dirweſtu, ymprydio. To abſtain from meat, to faſt.
Dirwŷ, trêth, (fforffet), (ffein). A Fine, a Penalty, a Forfeiture.
Dirwŷo, trethu, (ffeinio). To impoſe a Fine.
Diſas, ſal, dibrîs, gwael. Vile, baſe.
Disberod, rhodienna, cyfeiliorni. To go aſtray, to wander.
Disbwŷllo, gwneuthur yn ddoeth, iachâu. To make wiſe, to heal.
Disbyddu, gwâghâu. To evacuate, to make empty.
Diſgammar, ar waſgar, ar chwâl. Diſperſed, ſcattered.
Diſgethrin, llŷm, garw. Rough, ſharp, harſh.
Diſgogan, drogan, daroganu, (prophwŷdo). To divine, to prophecſie.
Diſgoganaf, daroganaf. I will propheſie or foretell.
Diſgreth, bloedd, bonllef. rhuad. An out-cry, a ſhout, a roaring.
Diſgriaw, llefain, dolefain, wŷlo. To exclaim, to make a noiſe, to weep.
Diſgybl, yr hwn a ddyſgo yſgolheigtod. A diſciple.
Diſgyfrith, llŷm, toſt, creulon. Auſtere, fierce cruel.
Diſgŷn. To come down, to deſcend.
Diſgyrnu dannedd, yſgyrnygu dannedd. To grin with the teeth.
Diſpaidd, a ſo wedi ei ddiſbaddu. That which is gelded.
Diffudd, wedi ſuddo neu foddi. Sunk, drowned.
Diſtain, (yſtiwart). A Steward, a ruler or governour, a captain of a guard.
Diſtreulio, treulio, gwarrio. To waſte, to conſume, to ſpend.
Diſtrewi, tiſio yn aml. To ſneeze often.
Diſtrych, ewŷn, trochion. ſcum, lather, froth.
Diſtŷll, llanw neu drai 'r môr. The flood or ebb of the ſea, alſo a diſtilling.
Diſtyllio, deſnynnu. To fall by drops, to diſtill.
Diſwŷdd, heb ſwŷdd. Private, without an office or imployment.
Diſwŷddo, troi un allan o'i ſwŷdd. To take away ones authority, to put one out of his Office.
Ditriwr, di dryfŵr, meudwŷ, gŵr crefyddol. A Religious man, an Hermit.
Diwad. Unhidden, openly, that cannot be denied.
Diwadnu. To ſupplant, to trip up ones heels.
Diwallttain, difalltrain, difrodi. To waſte, or conſume.
Diwanfa, cyfeiliorni, gwneuthur ar fai. To go aſtray, to err.
Diŵg, diguchiog, yn gwenu. Without frowns, ſmiling.
Diwraidd, heb wraidd. Extirpation, without root.
Diwreiddio. To pull up by the roots, to deſtroy.
Diwŷgio. To make better, to amend.
Diwŷll, diwyllio, addoli, hefyd aredig. To worſhip, alſo to till or plow.
Diwyllio duw, addoli duw. To worſhip God.
Diwyllio tîr, llafurio 'r ddaiar. To till the earth.
Diymwad, ſiccr, amlwg. Sure, manifeſt, which cannot be denied.

div.head: DO.
div.p: Dodi, rhoddi. To give, to put or ſet.
Doddoedd, fe ddaetheu. He had come.
Doddyw, daeth. He came, ſhe came.
Dôf. Tame, alſo I will come.
Dofraeth, dofreth trêth y pennau, taliad penn. Polemoney.
Doffr, diſt. The beam of a building.
Dogn. (Taſg), (Lwfiad). A task, an allowance, commons.
Dognedd, (meſur). rhŷw (feſur), rhŷw faint. A meaſure, a quantity.
Dôl, dolen. A bow or ring.
Dolennu, dolyftŷmmu. To bend, bow, or wind round.
Dolef, bloedd, gwaedd. A clamorous noiſe, an out-cry, a ſhout.
Dolefain, bloeddio. To cry out, to bawl.
Dolur. Diſeaſe, ſickneſs, ach, grief, pain.
Donwŷ, donnio, cynhyſgaeddu, rhoddi, rhoi. To endow, to give or beſtow.
Dorwn, dawr, cymmwys ŷw, gweddaidd ŷw. It behooves.
Dôs, defnŷn. A drop of any liquid thing.
Diddos, diddefni. That droppeth not, which leaketh not.
Doſparth, gwahaniaeth, hefŷd ſynwŷr. Diviſſon, diſtinction, alſo diſcretion.
Doſparthu, gwhanu, rhannu, hefŷd deall. To divide, to part, alſo to diſcern.
Dothŷw, daeth. He came, it came, ſhe came.
Dowŷdd, eſgoriad ar blant. The travel or labour of women in childbed.
Dowŷddu, eſgor ar blant. To travel of childs birth, to be in labour.

div.head: DR.
div.p: DRa, tra. While, until, beyond, above.
Draen, draenen. A thorn, a thorn-tree.
Draenllwŷn, dreinllwŷn, perth o ddrain. A buſh of thorns.
Draenog. A hedge hog, an urchin.
Dragio), rhwŷgo, dryllio. To tear in piecs.
Drannoeth. To morrow ſays Dr. Davies, but now taken for three days hence.
Drefa). A threave or 24. ſheaves of corn.
Drem, tremmiad, golygiad. The eye-ſight, alſo an Aſpect.
Drewi. A ſtink, alſo to ſtink.
Drewiant, dŷn gwael. A baſe or ſorry fellow.
Drudwŷ, drudwen, yderŷn y drudwŷ. A bird called a Starling or Stare.
Dryglam. Miſhap, misfortune, an ill end, unnatural death.
Drygnaws. Frowardneſs, alſo an evil conſtitution of body.
Drygwŷnt. A ſtink, a noiſom air.
Drygyrſerthu, galaru. To lament, to mourn.
Drychiolaeth, gwàg-yſgrŷd. A phantaſie, a viſion.
Drylwŷn, buan, parod. Quick, ready, expedite.
Drŷll, darn. A piece or part.
Dryllio. To tear, to cut in pieces.
Drylliog. Torn, rent, cut to pieces.
Dryntol, dyrntol, dyrnddôl, dôl ddwrn, drantol. The handle of a cup or flagon, &c.
Drŷw. A bird called a Wren.

div.head: DU.
div.p: Dûo. To blacken, alſo to grow black.
Dûeg, cleddyſ bleddŷn, y cleddyf biſwail. The milt, the ſpleen.
Dul, ffat, dyrnod. A ſtroke, a blow.
Dull, môdd, yſtum, ſut. Form, faſhion.
Dullio, mathu, yſtummio. To form, to faſhion.
Duno, dyuno, cyttruno. To accord, to agree.
Durſing, creulon, caled fel dûr. Auſtere, hard like ſteel.
Durŷn, turs. A birds bill, a ſnout.

div.head: DW.
div.p: Dwbler, deſgil fawr, cawg. A great platter, a charger, a baſon.
Dwfr-iàr. A ſea fowl, a fenduck.
Dyfrlle, lle'rhedô dŵr. The channel of a river.
Dwnn, lliw rhŷdd tywŷll. Somewhat brown, duskiſh, ſwarthy.
Dwrdd, trwſt, sŵn. A noiſe, a ſtir.
Dyrnod. A box or blow with the fiſt, a ſtroke.
Dwſel, piſtŷll, (ffowſet). A ſpout, a water-cock, a tap.
Dwſmel, màth ar offerŷn cerdd. A dulcimer.
Dwŷliw, dwŷlŷw, dwŷ blaid. Two partys.
Dwŷn. To carry, to bear, alſo to ſteal.
Dwŷnfŷg, yn dwŷn anrhydedd. Bearing honour.
Dwŷre, cyfodi, eſmwytho, eſmwythau. To riſe, to eaſe.
Dwŷreawr, dringhedŷdd, neu un yn dringo. A climber.

div.head: DY.
div.p: Dyar, trwſt, sŵn. A noiſe, a ſtir.
Dybi, bi, fe fŷdd. It will come to paſs.

Dyborthi, dwyn, dioddef,
cynnal. To carry, to bear.
Dybu, daeth. He came, it came, ſhe came.
Dybŷdd, bŷdd. It will be, it will come to paſs.
Dychan, gogan-gerdd. A Satyre, an Invective Poem, a carping Song.
Dychlammu, llammu, cyrchneitio. To leap, to jump, to pant.
Dychlud, cludo ynghŷd, yfed. To bear or carry together, to convey, alſo to drink.
Dychludedd, yfed ynghŷd, cŷd-yfed. Comportation or drinking together.
Dychrain, ſyrthio ar wŷneb. To proſtrate, to do homage.
Dychrêu, cogor, creu fel bràn. To croake like a crow.
Dychrŷn, dychry ndod, oſn. Fear, trembling, horrour.
Dychryſio, cryſio, bryſio. To make haſte, to haſten.
Dychwedl, chwedl▪ A tale a report.
Dychwelŷd, troiynèl. To turn back. to return.
Dychyfŷd, fe gyfŷd. He ſhal riſe, he will riſe.
Dychfrŷ, a gynhyrfo. The may or ſhall move.
Dychymmell, gwaſgu, cymmal. To preſs, to compel or force.
Dychymmŷg. A Riddle, a hard Queſtion.
Dychymmuſg, cymmyſgu. To mingle or mix together.
Dychynnau, cynneu. To kindle, to light.
Dychyrch, ymgŷrch, rhuthr. An aſſault, a violence.
Dyd, mae ef yn dyfod, He cometh.
Dyddio, gwneuthur tangnefedd. To agree, to compoſe a difference.
Dyddiwr, cylafareddwr, heddychwr. An Arbitratour, a peace-maker.
Dŷdd-brawd. dŷdd y farn. The day of Judgment, Dooms day.
Dŷdd pennod, dŷdd (pwŷntiedig). An appointed day.
Dyddelwi, glaſu, amliwio. To wax pale.
Dyddfu, diffygio, pallu. To lack or fail.
Dyddoddŷw, doddŷw, daeth ef. He came.
Dyddŷm, dyddymmu, dielwi, gwneuthur, yn ddiddeunŷdd. To repeal, to diſannul to aboliſh.
Dyfalu neu laſenwi. To miſcal or nick-name.
Dyfalu neu ddychymmygu. To conjecture or gueſs at.
Dyflôen darn, dellten. A piece, a ſplinter.
Dyfnu, ſugno allan. To ſuck or draw out.
Dyfnad, un yn ſugno. A ſucker.
Dyfriâr, dwfriar, hwŷad wŷllt. A fen-duck, a wild-duck.
Dyfrydedd, dyfrydwch, anhyfrydwch, hefŷd hiraeth. Vnpleaſant, alſo longing.
Dyfrydio, brydio, tywŷmno. To warm, to heat.
Dyfryſio, bryſſio, pryſſuro. To make haſte.
Dyfyddi, deui, doi, cei ddyfod. Thou ſhalt come.
Dyfŷn, rhybŷdd i ddyfod yn dŷſt. A Summon.
Dyfŷnwallaw, dyfnallaw, rhybŷddio i dyſtiolaethu. To ſummon.
Dyfŷr, difŷr, difir. Pleaſant, delightſom, jocund, merry.
Dyfyrru. To make ſport, to make merry, to make deligtſom.
Dyfyſgu, terfŷſg, anrhefn, cymmŷſg. A tumult, confuſion.
Dyffo, deuo, delo. May or can come.
Dyffwn, deuwn, down. Let us come, we will come.
Dygludo, dwyn ynghŷd. To bring together.
Dyglŷw, clŷw. Hark thou, hear thou.
Dygn, dygŷn. Severe. in great meaſure.
Dygnu, trallodi, Cyſtuddio. To trouble, to afflict.
Dygyfor, cyffro, rhuad dyfroedd. A tumult, the noiſe of waters.
Dyhêu, dyhêad. To pant, to blow, to throb.
Dyhinedd, dryccin. A tempeſt, a ſtorm.
Dyhuddiant, dyhŷddiad. A pacifying, pleaſing, qualifying.
Dyhuddai, un yn dyhaddo. A pacifier.
Dyhysbyddu, disbyddu, gwaghâu. To evacuate or make empty.
Dylaith, dolen. A bow or ring.
Dyledog, breiniol, Urddaſrŷw. Noble, Generous, a Peer, Imperial.
Dyledowgrŷw, bonheddig. Noble, of Noble ſtock.
Dyli, cyflwr y corph. The habit of the body.
Dylifo. The warping of a web, alſo to warp a web, to rid through the bands.
Dylofŷn, dylŵf, dyrnaid, cudŷn o wlân. A handful, a lock of wool.
Dyludo, erlid, calyn yn gloſs. To follow hard, to purſue.
Dylyfu gên. To gape, to yawn.
Dyluſg, carthion, bŷdreddi. Filth or off ſcouring, alſo the common-ſewer.
Dylyn, dilyn. To follow after, to purſue.
Dylu, dyleu. To owe, to be in debt.
Dymbi, bydd. It ſhall be, it will he.
Dymddwŷn, ymddwŷn. To behave one ſelf.
Dymuno, damuno. To requeſt, to deſire.
Dynionach, dynion gwael. Men of no regard.
Dyno, dynan, corr. A little dwarf, one of no reputation.
Dyneſſu, dyneſſau, neſſu. To aproach, to draw near.
Dynoethi, dinoethi, noethi. To make bare or naked.
Dyphorthi, porthi. To feed or ſupply with.
Dyrain, chwenychu. To luſt, to covet.
Dyrannu, rhannu. To part, to divide.
Dyrchafu, myned i fynu. To aſcend.
Dyrchafad, dyrchafael, dyrchafiad, mynediad i fynu. Aſcenſion
Dyre, dyred, tyred ymma. Come thou hither.
Dyrllyddd, derllŷdd, darllenŷdd, darllenwr. A Reader.
Dyrrwŷf, dyrwŷf, rwy 'n neſsâu. I approach or draw near.
Dyrŷdd, rhŷdd, efe a rŷdd. He will give.
Dyryſu, dryſu, rhwyſtro. To intangle, to incumber.
Dyſgammar, diſgammar, ar waſgar. Diffuſed, ſpread abroad.
Dyſgl, deſgil. A diſh, a platter.
Dyſgogan, darogan, prophwŷdoliaeth. An Oracle, a Prophecy, an Augury
Dyſgweinid, hwy a weiniaſant. They ſerved or miniſtred.
Dyſpeidio, peidio. To ceaſe, to intermit.
Dyuno, duno, cydtuno. To conſent, to agree.
Dyundeb, dundeb, cydtundeb. Conſent, unity, concord.
Dywallaw, Tywallt. To pour, to pour cut.
Dyweddi. A Contract or betroathing of a Man and Woman before full Marriage.
Dywelling, diwall; heb eiſieu dim. Abounding, wanting nothing.
Dywrthred. Gwrthred. Mynediad yn ôl. A Retrogradation, or going backward.
Dywynnŷg, llewyrchu, ymddangos. To ſhine, to appear.

div.head: EB.
div.p: EAng, eheng. Wide, large, ample; alſo free.
Ebach, cilfach. A Straight, a Haven, an Angle or corner.
Ebill. An augre, wimble or piercer; alſo the pin of a harp or lute.
Eblliio. To hore a hole with an augre.
Ebodni, eſmwytho 'r corph. To diſcharge or exonerate the belly.
Ebolŷdd, yrowan, yn fŷan. Even now, by and by, forthwith.
Ebrwŷdd, bŷan. Swift, ſuddenly, in haſte.
Ebrwch, ychenaid. A ſigh, a grean.

div.head: ECH.
div.p: Echdywynnu, echdywynnygu, tywŷnnu. To ſhine, to glitter.
Echdywynnedig, diſglaer, tywŷnnedig. Bright, ſhining, glittering.
Echel, extro. An axle-tree, the North and South Poles, the Meridian line.
Echen, achen, cenedl, pobol. A Nation or People.
Echlys, echlvsŷr, achlysŷr, achos. A cauſe or occaſion.
Echrŷn, crynfa. A trembling fear, horrour.
Echrys-haint, adwŷth. A blaſting, or benumming.
Echudd, yn guddiedig. In ſecret, hidden.
Echwng, wng, yn agos, tuagat. Near, towards:
Echwŷdd, hwŷr, tua 'r hwŷr. Late in the evening.
Echwŷn, nechwŷn, benthig. Borrowed, that which is horrowed or lent.
Echwŷrth, lledechwyrth, ynfŷd, anwŷbodol. Fooliſh, rude, doting.

div.head: ED.
div.p: Edfrŷd, rhoddi i fymr, rhoddi heibio, rhoddi yn ol. To render or yield up; alſo reſtauration.
Edgy • aeth, triſtwch, trymder, galar. Sorrow, heavìneſs; lamenting.
Edlaes, llaes. Deep towards the ground, long downward.
Edling, brenhinawl heppil neu deulu. A Royal off-ſpring or generation.
Edlynu, diwŷno. To ſpat, ſlabber or ſoile.
Edlŷm, llŷmm. Sharp-edged, alſo ſevere, rigid.
Edmygu, urddaſu, clodfori. To honour, to praiſe, to glorifie.
Edn, aderŷn. A bird, a fowl.
Ednogŷn, gwybedŷn. A gnat, a flie.
Ednŷdd, pôſt llidiart. The poſt of a gate.
Edrin, trin. Exerciſe, work, pains alſo Battle, alſo to dreſs, attend, order or look after.
Edrŷch. See thou, behold thou, alſo to behold, to look.
Edryd, edrŷf, rhŷw, cenedl. A Stock or Family, Kindred.
Edrydd, adroddwr, un a adroddo achos. He that declareth a cauſe.
Edrywan, edrywant, trywanu, brathu trwodd, rhedeg trwodd. To bore or pierce through, to ſtab.
Edrywedd, tryedd, ôlrheniad. A ſcent, a trace of track.
Edwi, pallu, methu. To languiſh, to was faint or feeble.
Edwin, pall, methiant. Faint or feeble, lean, poor.
Edwino, methu, lleſghau, pallu. To pine away or languiſh.
Eddeifniad, un yn ſugno. He that draweth or ſucketh.
Eddrin, edrinaw, ymarfer, rhyfela, ymladd. To exerciſe, to work, to war, to fight, alſo to uſe or accuſtom.
Eddŷl, cenedl, pobl Teyrnas. A Nation, Kindred or People.

div.head: EF.
div.p: Efengŷl, newŷdd dâ. Goſpel or glad tidings.
Efelychu, dynwared, dilyn. To imitate, to reſemble, to do to the life.
Efellgŷr, efŷll, a ener ar unwaith o'r un wraig ydŷnt efeillion. Twins.
Efrai, Iaith yr (Hebræaid.) The Hebrew Tongue.
Efrifed, afrifed, aneirif, heb rifedi. Innumerable, infinite.
Efrllid, twrndà, cymwŷnas, haeddiant. A good turn, merit or deſert.
Efrŷdd, anafus. Maimed, lame, with blemiſh, alſo ruinous.
Efydden, efyddŷn, pair, padell o efŷdd. A caldron, kettle or pan of copper.

div.head: EFF.
div.p: Effros, màth ar Lyſieuŷn. The herb Eye-bright.

div.head: EG.
div.p: Egluro. To manifeſt, to explain, alſo to clear up, to make viſible.
Egni. Vehement endeavour, force or vigour.
Egnius, egniol. Striving with all might, ſtrong, mighty.
Egroes, cwlm, cwlwm gwelltŷn ŷd. The knot or joynt of ſtanding corn.
Egrŷn, ofn, dychrynfa. Fear, trembling, alſo a rude or uncivil perſon.
Egweddi, cynhyſgaeth. A Dowry, a Portion.
Egwŷd, meinedd coes ceffŷl. The ſmalleſt of a horſe's leg called the Lock of the foot.
Egwŷddor, ſef y lythyrennau. An Alphabet, an A. B C. A Catechiſm.

div.head: EH.
div.p: Ehengu. To amplifie, to draw out in breadth or length, to enlarge.
Ehôeg, lliw gwŷrdd. A green Colour.
Ehorth, eorth aſtud, myfyriog. Diligent, ſtudious.
Ehud, hawdd ei dwyllo, ynfŷd. Raſh, eaſie to be deceived, ſimple.
Edhudrwydd, tragwŷ chder, hŷ ynfydrwydd. Raſhneſs.

div.head: EI.
div.p: EI, yr eiddo ef, yr eiddo hi. His, hers.
Eich, yr eiddo chwi. Your, Yours.
Eidiog, bywiog, nwyfus. Quick, nimble, lively amorous.
Eidion. An ox bull, or bullock.
Eiddig, yr hwn a fô yn eiddigeddu. He that is jealous.
Eiddigedd, ofn bôd un arall yn mwŷnhau y péth a garo un ei hun. Jealouſie.
Eiddigeddu, ofni bôd un arall yn mwynhau yr hŷn a garo un ei hunan. To be jealous.
Eiddilo. To make ſlender or ſmall.
Eiddo. His, hers, the owning of a thing.
Eiddun, eidduned, adduned, llŵ, diofrŷd. A Vow.
Elddiuno, rhoddi diofrŷd neu lŵ. To make a vow.
Eiddwng, cymmydog, hefŷd agos. A Neighbour, alſo near.
Eigian, igian. The yexing or hick, the hickock.
Eigion, y gwaelod eithaf. The very bottom.
Eilio. To weave, to knit or intangle, to platt together.
Eiliw, lliw, llûn. A colour, a figure, image, form or ſhape.
Eilon, carw ieuaingc. A young deer.
Eilwers, etto, o'i newŷdd, drachefen, hefyd yn erbŷn. Afreſh, again, alſo againſt.
Ein, eiddo ni, yr eiddo ni. Our, ours.
Eingl, gelynion, hefyd dieithraid. Forreigners, ſtrangers, alſo enemies.
Einiwo, niweidio. To burt, to damage.
Eirchiad, y neb a archo, hefŷd y neb a ddymuno. A petitioner, an asker, alſo a bidder.
Aneirif, mwy na rhif, mwy nag a ellir eu rhifo. Innumerable.
Eiriol, eirioli. Ymbil neu ddymuno dros un arall. To intercede, mediate or intreat for another.
Eirionŷn, yrionŷn. The ſelvage or liſt of cloth.
Eirionyn tîr, terfŷn tîr, nôd yn terfynu tîr. A Land-mark.
Eiſieu, eiſiwed, angen. Indigence, want, need.
Eiſilling, Eiſill ŷeld, heppil. An Off-ſpring, Pregeny.
Eiſin. Bran, the husks of corn.
Eiſingrug, twrr o eiſin. A heap of bran, or corn-husks.
Eiſoes, etto, er hynnu. Yet, Notwithſtanding.
Eithr, oblegŷd, o herwŷdd, ond. Without, beſides, but, becauſe.
Eithrad, dieithr, dieithr ddŷn A ſtranger, a forreigner.

div.head: EL.
div.p: ELain, carw ieuaingc. A hind-calf, a little fallowdeer.
Elcys, elcyſen, gŵŷdd wŷllt. A wild-gooſe.
Elech, llêch garreg, carregfedd. A graven-ſtone; alſo a ſlate, a ſtone-table, a bakeſtone.
Eleſtron, eleſtr, mâth ar lyſieuŷn. The herb called the Flower de Luce.
Elfennau, i mae pedwar mâth o elfennau, ſef awŷr, daiar, dŵr, tân. Elements.
Elfyddu, tebygu, cyffelybu. To compare or liken.
Elgeth, aelgeth, gên, bôch. The chin, the cheek.

Elin, cufŷdd, hud aſgwrn
gŵr o 'i arddwrn iw bynnelin. A cubit.
Elor, gelor, elorwŷdd. A bier to carry dead corps upon.
Els, mab ynghyfraith. A Son-in-law, a Step-ſon.
Elſes merch ynghyfraith. A Daughter in-law.
Elwa, gwneuthŷr ennil. To gain, to profit.
Elwig, ffurf neu lûn, lluniaidd. A figure, form or ſhape, ſhapeable.
Anelwig, affluniaidd. Without form, ill ſhap'd.
Elydn, elydr, (Ambr,) cymmyſg o aur ag Arian, hefyd (Haiarn) (Coppor) (prês). Amber, a mixture of Gold and Silver, alſo tin; Copper, Braſs, Iron.
Elŷf, annelŷf, tynnŷ bwa, sêlu at- To mark, to leavel at, to bend or draw a bow.
Elŷff, elyffu, trais, gormes, heſŷd cornwŷd. Oppreſſion, force, treſpaſs; alſo a plague.

div.head: ELL.
div.p: Elldrewŷn, mam ynghy-fraith. A Step-mother, a mother in-law.
Ellwng, gollwng. To looſe or let looſe, alſo leak or let through.
Ellŷll. A phantaſie, a goblin, a hobgoblin.
Ellyll-dân, tan ellŷll, tân yn rhodio 'r nôs. A walking fire called Will with a wiſp.
Ellŷnedd, Erllynedd, yllynedd. The laſt year.

div.head: EM.
div.p: Eminiog, hiniog, rhiniog. The threſhold, a door-ſill.
Emlŷn, ymlŷn, erlŷn, calŷn, ymlid. To purſue, to follow.
Enlyniad, ymlyniad, un a erlyno neu a galyno arall. He that purſues or follows.
Emrain, ymrain, hâd hiliogaeth. The ſeed of generation.
Emrwŷs, clôd, hefŷd ymryſon. Praiſe, alſo ſtrife.
Emŷl, ymmŷl The frontier or border, the hem or skirt of a garment, the brim of a cup or put, a rim, an edge.
Emŷn, cân o fawl i dduw. An Hymn.

div.head: EN.
div.p: ENad, genedigol, yr hwn a anwŷd. A native.
Eneldiol, ag enaid ynddo. Endowed with a Soul.
Eneidrwŷdd, neidrwŷdd, ar leiſiau y pen. The temples of the head.
Encil, ffo, cîl. A flight, a retreat, abſconding.
Encilio, ffoi, cilio. To flie, to withdraw out of the way or abſcond.
Engi, eſgor. To bring forth, to produce.
Engyll, Angell, yſgwydd neu fraich, aſgell. The ſhoulder, or arm of a man, the pinion of a bird, a wing.
Eniwo, niweid o, briwo. To hurt, to offend.
Enllib, drŵg-abſen, athrod, gogan ar gam. Calumny, reproach, ſlander.
Enllibio, goganu un heb haeddu. To calumniate, to reproach, to backbite.
Enllŷn. All manner of things that are to be eaten with bread.
Ennylu, plygu, ſelu. To bend, to level.
Ennŷn, ennynnu, nynnu. To kindle to burn.
Ennynfa, nynfa. A burning flame alſo hatred.
Eatyrch entrŷch, brîg, uchder. The top, the height.
Enwog. Illuſtrious, Noble in renown, excellent, famous
Enwogi. To make noble or renown'd, to make famous.
Enwir, drygionus, diried, an nuwiol. Wicked, ungodly.

div.head: EO.
div.p: Eorth, aſtud, myfyriog, yſtig. Studious, diligent.
Eos, aderyn a gàn yn llafar. The nightingale.

div.head: EP.
div.p: Eppa, dynwarredwr: (Siaccanàp). An ape, alſo he that endeavoureth to do as he ſees another.
Eppilio. To increaſe a Stock or Lineage.

div.head: ER.
div.p: Ebylu, pylu. To make dull or blunt.
Erbŷn. Towards, againſt, by, right againſt.
Erbŷn, derbyn. To receive, to accept.
Erch, lliw, hefŷd cethin. A colour; alſo cruel, horrible, terrible.
Erchi. A bidding, alſo to bid.
Erchwŷn. The ſide poſt of a bedſtid.
Erchyllu. To abhor, alſo to be horrible, to be unpleaſant to the eye.
Erchyll, briw, twn croen. A wouna.
Erddigan, cyſſondeb. Harmony, concent in muſick.
Erddrŷm, gwrol, gwrymmus. Strong, valiant, manly.
Erddygnawd, dygnawd, trymder meddwl. Trouble, anxiety, ſorrow.
Erfawr, dirfawr, mawr iawn. Very great.
Erfid, amcanion i daraw. Attempts or endeavours to ſmite.
Erglywed, clywed. Hearing, alſo to hear.
Frgrŷd, crynfa. A trembling or horrour.
Ergrŷn, crynfa. A ſhaking or trembling.
Ergyr, cynnwrf mawr. A vehement motion, a perſwaſion.
Ergyrwauw, gwthiad gwauwffon. The thruſt of a ſpear.
Erioed. In all times paſt, alſo in no time paſt or never yet.
Eclid, ymlid, calŷn ar ôl. To perſecute, to purſue, to follow after.
Ermid), meudwŷ, gŵr crefyddol. An Hermit.
Ermi ledd, Bŷwoliaeth Ermid neu feudwŷ. An aſcetick life, the life of a Hermit.
Ermideddawg, yn bŷw bŷwoliaeth Ermid. Leading a Hermit's life.
Ermŷg, offerŷn, rhaiadr neu gwymp dwfr. An Inſtrument; alſo a Cataract or great downfall of waters.
Ern, ernes, (Erneſt). An ear neſt or pledge to confirm a bargain.
Ernŷw, erniwed, niweidio. To hurt, to harm.
Ertrai, trai 'r môr. The ebbing of the ſea.
Erthychain. To grunt, puff or blow.
Erthylu. To bring forth before the time.
Erw. An acre of land; alſo a little cloſe of ground.
Erwân, gwân, piggiad, brâth. A prick or ſtab.
Erwŷdd. Rods for perches, or to hedge with.
Erŵŷr, gŵŷr, cam, an union. Crooked, waryed.
Erŷl, treſn, An order or method.
Erythiolaf, gweddio. To pray, to give thanks.

div.head: ES.
div.p: EShorthiaid, maethyddion. Nouriſhers or bringers up.
Eſgair, coes. A leg or ſhank.
Eſgar, gelŷn, gwrthwŷncbŵr. An enemy, an adverſary.
Eſgarant, eſgeraint, gelynion, gwrthwŷnebwŷr. Adverſaries, enemies.
Eſgor. To bring forth, to be brought to bed.
Eſgud, bywiog, dyfal. Luſty, active, diligent.
Eſguraw, curaw, curo. To beat, to knock.
Eſgŷn, eſgynnu, derchafu, myned i fynu. To aſcend.
Eſgynfa, mynediad i fynu, gâllt. An aſcent.
Eſill, eſſillŷdd, eſſilltŷdd, ſilltŷdd, hîl, heppil. A progeny or off-ſpring.
Eſmwytho, eſmwythâu. To mollify, to ſoften, to eaſe.
Eſtron. One not related, a ſtranger, a forreigner.
Eſtŷn. To ſtretch, to extend, to reach.

div.head: ET.
div.p: Ethol, dethol, deffol, dewis. To chooſe.
Ethrefig, cartrefig, trigfa, cartref. One's habitation or home.
Ethrŷb, achos. A cauſe, an occaſion.
Ethrywŷn, athrywŷn. To part or put aſunder them that fight.
Etto, etwa, atwaeth. As yet, yet, again.

div.head: EU.
div.p: Euddon, gwraint, cynchawn Man. Hand-worms, mites or ſmall maggots.
Eulon geifr, cagl geifr. Goats dung.
Eulŷn, eilun, llun, delw. An linage.
Euod, llynger. The belly or maw worms.
Euog, haeddol o goſbedigaeth. Guilty, faulty.
Eurin, eurinawl, euraid, o aur. Golden.
Eurŷch, A goldſmith, alſo a braſier, a tinker.

Eurychaeth, celfyddŷd yr eurŷch. The art of a goldſmith,
braſier or tinker.

div.head: EW
div.p: Ewig. A hind, a doe, alſo a young ſtagg or hart.
Ewin, The nail of a finger or toe, alſo a bird's claw.
Ewinallt, gallt ſerth. A precipice, a ſteepy aſcent.
Ewŷbr, yn fuan, yn (ſydŷn.) Soon, quickly, ſpeedily.
Ewŷllŷs. Will, a will, a deſire or inclination.
Ewŷlly io. To will, to deſire.
Ewynnu, malu ewŷn. To fome or froth.
Ewŷngant, gwŷndra ewŷn. The whiteneſs of fome or froth.

div.head: FA.
div.p: Fagddu, y fagddu, tywŷllwch heb ddim goleini. Utter darkneſs.
Fano, llwŷddo, tyccio. To proſper or ſpeed.
Fal, fel, mal. As, even as.
Fal hŷn, fel hŷn. Thus, ſo.
Fall, drygioni, dyreidi. Evil, miſchief, belial.
Plant y fall, plant drwg. The children of belial.

div.head: FE.
div.p: Fed, hŷd, hŷd oni. Even to. untill.

div.head: FR.
div.p: Frech, dolur a wnelo frychni. A pox.

div.head: FY.
div.p: Fŷg fàg, mŷg, mewn anrhefn, cymſŷg. Confuſedly, mixt.
Fyrr, pren ffynnidwŷdd. A Firr tree.

div.head: FFA.
div.p: Ffaelu, cam-gymmerŷd. To miſtake, to deceive or be deceived.
Ffaeth, peraidd, meddal, addfed, Mellow, ripe, ſoft.
Ffaglawr, ffaglwr. He that ſets on fire, or ſets one againſt another.
Ffagod) (ffagoden,) cidyſen. A faggot, a bavin.
Ffald,) corlan. A ſheep fold, a fold.
Ffalm, ffalm-wynt, gwynt mawr. Boiſterous or great wind.
Ffallach, ffollach, yſanau byttym mog. Buſkins.
Ffat, dul, Lab, dyrnod. A ſtripe, a ſtroke, a blow.
Ffaw, Arglwŷdd, hefŷd anrhydedd. A Lord, alſo Honour.

div.head: FFE.
div.p: Ffelaig, pennaeth llu. A generall, a Captain.
Ffer y troed. The ankle or ankle bone of the foot.
Fferr, fferdod, anwŷd dirfawr, Rhŷn. Extreame col.
Fferru, rhynnu. To wax extreame cold, to periſh with cold.
Fferm,) tyddŷn. A manner, a farm.
Ffettan, ſach. A ſack or bagg.
Ffeutur, tŷnn, plwm gwyn, Tinn, white lead.

div.head: FFI
div.p: Ffilog, choles. hefŷd aſgell. A filly, alſo the wing of a foul, the ſicke of a wheel.
Ffilores, merch yn chwareu ar dannau. A woman muſitian.
Ffiloreg, gwâg ſiarad. Vain-talking or babling.
Ffin,) diwedd, gorffen. Finis, an end.
Ffin) dirwŷ, camlwrw, (fforffet,) treth. A fine, a tax, a forfeit.
Ffinio) goſod (fforffet,) trethu. To fine, to tax.
Ffiol fresŷch, (ſowſer,) A plate trencher, or ſawcer.

div.head: FFL.
div.p: Fflaggio, pallu, methu. To decay, to fade away, to flag.
Fflammîo.) To kindle or flame. alſo to be inflamed.
Fflaw, agen, dellten, (banner.) A flaw, a ſplinter, Banner, Flag or Enſign.
Fflureg, penn blaen llong. The foredeck or caſtie of a ſhip.
Ffluwch, cudyn o wallt. A buſh of hair, or lock of hair.
Fflŵch, gwrol, gwrymmus, hael. Valiant, luſty, active, liberall.

div.head: FFO.
div.p: FFò. A flight, to flie or eſcape out of the way.
Ffoadur, diengwr. A runnagate, a fugitive.
Ffolen, bontin. A buttock or haunch.
Ffollach, bwtiasen, hoſan fytymmog. A boot, a buſkin.
Ffonwauw, gwauwffon, ffon fawr bigog i ryfela. A ſpear.
Fforddio, hyfforddio. To direct. one in the way.
Fforddrŷch, cydnabyddus ar ffordd. Aquainted in the way.

Fforio, (yſpio) chwilio. To
ſpie, to ſearch.
Fforiwr, (yſpiŵr) chwiliwr. A ſpie, or ſpier, a ſearcher.
Ffoſs, ffoffwn, cleddŷf,) (hanger.) A ſword, a hanger.
Ffoſſod, ffoſſawd dyrnod cleddŷf. A ſtroke or blow with a ſword.
Efothell, chwŷſigen, llinorŷn. a Puſh or bliſter, a wheal or pimple.
Ffoure, brŷn ymddiffynfa. A hill of refuge or defence.

div.head: FFR.
div.p: Ffrau, ffreu, rhŷdd, ymroſgo. Looſe, large, alſo a battle
Ffrautur, brawdoliaeth o wŷr crefyddol. A fraternity of religious men.
Ffrawdd, ffrawd, niwed, briw. Harm, hurt.
Ffrecc, ſiaradeach, gwag ſiarad Tatling, babbling, prating.
Ffrengig, bytheiad gwaedlŷd. A blood hound, a draught hound.
Ffrewŷll, fflangell, (chwip.) A ſcourge, a whip.
Ffrewyllio, fflangellu, (chwipio.) To whip, to ſcourge.
Ffriſtial, ffriſtiol, blwch i daflu diſſiau o honaw. A box uſed to caſt diſe out of.
Ffrith, ffridd. Plowed land lately taken out of a mountain.
Ffroeni, ffroenio. To blow or breath at the noſtrils, to ſnurt.
Ffroenfoll, ffroenlydan. Having open or wide noſtrils.
Ffrom, Brochus, digllon. Fuming, angry, fretful.
Ffrommi, digio, brochi. To fume, to murmur to wax angry.
Ffrongc, Cûtt gwŷddau. A Cage to feed Geeſe in.
Ffrŵŷno. To bridle, to refrain, to conſtrain.
Ffwŷth. Fruit, alſo Life or motion.
Ffrwvtho. To bear fruit, to fructifie.

div.head: FFV
div.p: Ffuantwr, Rhagrithiŵr, gwenheithiwr: a Hypocrite, a Diſſembler.
Ffugiol, Celwŷddog: Lying, or given to deceive.
Ffullio, bryſſio: to haſten, to make ſpeed.
Ffunell, lloned llaw: a handful, a gript or handful bound together.
Ffunud, môdd, yſtŷm, ſutt: manner, figure or form.
Ffûr, doeth, dyſgedig: wiſe, learned, cautious.
Ffured:) a Beaſt called a Ferret.
Ffurf,) môdd, ſutt, yſtŷm: a form or method.
